review_title: Constant layoffs, zero culture, all it matters is the stock value
pros: They pay a salary (sometimes)
cons: Job security is non existent

review_title: It's OK, you will always have a job here
pros:
- Name recognition, IBM gets you in the door
- Very ethical company
- Great work life balance
- Good "people" management, 1st line managers are very understanding when it comes to problems or issues.  
- Client-centric company, client relationships are respected and IBM acts very professionally when dealing with its clients
cons:
- Company is cheap, feels like we are going out of business despite the surge in stock price
- Below average compensation.
- Average benefits package.
- Poor bonuses, even in sales.  This is NOT the place to get rich.  Bonuses in non-client facing jobs are virtually non-existent
- Not challenging, I can do my job in my sleep, and I've raised this to my management, nothing has changed.
- Lack of career assistance/planning, you're really left on your own to figure out your path through the machine.  Unsurprisingly, this makes vertical moves near impossible unless you're a superstar (which is odd given the mediocrity in first line management).

review_title: Disappointed at working well under my capacity and capability
pros:
Can be well paid. There can be opportunities to move and expand experience.
It is very collegial, and they do take good care of people especially in an emergency or crisis.
The company does do a very good job of communicating with people the state of the business, current issues and plans.
cons: The culture is all embracing ad overwhelming. It is fundamentally run by Finance, with sales people being revered. Working internally as I did is neither appreciated or valued. I worked for a global team for years yet it never met in person due to a complete ban on travel expense for internal people. In 8 years I never did any training, never met any clients, never was able to go to any trade shows (even IBM run ones). There are no doubt some excellent managers and leaders though unfortunately I never worked for any. A lot of the people there joined as graduates and have only ever worked for IBM - these people occupy most if not all of the senior roles.

review_title: Elephants CAN dance!  But they will kill you!
pros: Great technology and lots of smart folks.  100% self direction, no micro-management.  A company big enough to have expertise in nearly everything and if they don't they carry enough influence with partners to assure someone gets on a plane to help finish a difficult project if needed.
cons:
These are near endless, just like the hours, phone calls and failure of the internal systems.  Most folks with any tenure work in international teams.  This means continual early morning or late night conference calls that when added up will equal 70+ hours per week.

In the extra time an employee has between 6am and 11PM calls,  one must fit in time for expense reports, booking travel and answering emails.   The travel booking system is abysmal, the expense report system is very difficult to use when it works at all, and the email system is extremely flaky.

review_title: We're too Big to help you
pros: Excellent place to get a start working, especially if you're fresh out of university. They will take you on board under a Consultants by Degree program.  Here you'll learn all about consulting.
cons: You are on your own.  This company has the worst on boarding program I've ever seen.  You're left to sort out your own benefit options.  You're left on your own basically to manage your own career.  No guidance, and the mentoring program is a program in name only.  You're treated as a number, and how many billable numbers you produce. Never mind all the behind-the-scenes work one does supporting projects or helping win new work.  None if it counts at the end of the year.   Finally, their resource managers are the worst communicators.  You can be the most qualified individual to fill a role, but they will hire an outside resource if you are ________ (fill in the blank, 'too far', 'too high band', 'not fluent enough in French".

job_title: Services Sales Representative in Smyrna, GA
pros: IBM offers great benefits to its employees - affordable healthcare, purchasing discounts, sick leave, 401K and stock purchase plans.
cons: Beware of success.  If you perform a job well at the Smyrna Call Center, you will be consigned to that role forever unless you do so serious internal politicking.  You have managers who've never done the roles they manage and therefore lack any ability to relate to the sales reps or understand what it takes to meet/exceed your quota.  I personally encountered some of the most dysfunctional, petty first line managers in my entire sales career.  At least two (2) desperately needed therapy (world class narcissists) and had no business managing people.  Also, the Smyrna location is a haven for positions awarded through entitlement, not skill.  In the words of another manager who left, "If you are not a manager here, you are not a citizen."  I was not a citizen.  I left after five years and never looked back.

pros: Great salary, great traninng programs that give you the chance to network with many college hires in the program.
cons: The program advertises the benefit of moving around/rotating to other projects during the 2 year duration of the program. In my experience, I've had many difficulties moving to other projects in the public sector and have been on my first project for a year plus now. My managers are not helpful and really have an "oh well" attitude when I express that I want to move around to gain different experiences. It's a very tough spot when you want to learn and soak in as much information and possible, but no one is there to help.

review_title: Consulting Division was a daily struggle against the forces of complacency and chaos...
job_title: Open Systems Engineer in Atlanta, GA
pros:
The check cashed and I consider that an upside.
They don't call you much after hours which was a big upside having been on call for years.
Everyone worked from home and that was made this place initially so attractive.
When you don't have anything else to do at least you can read manuals or other tech documents and they have some really good ones.
cons:
No IBMer manager or employee would rock the boat to help the customer at all in my opinion.
They would do whatever it took to ensure that their pay/benefits would continue another day.
They seemed to have some processes so canned that they were painful and others totally without process at all. 
Teams and management seemed to struggle with the most trivial issues.
Each group seemed to fight one another to the detriment of the customer at least in the group for which I was a consultant.

pros:
Most people there are hard working and easy to get on with.
Working from home (at manager's discretion).
cons:
Unsustainable High Workload.

Even if you worked 24/7 it still wouldn't be enough.

People leaving and not being replaced but the workload is still expected to be covered.

Training is nonexistent. You are expected to train and up skill on your own time. Even if your training is relevant to your job, management may not accept it as part of your training for the year. 

Bullying by certain managers is rife and if you try to bring it up, you will be warned and attacked by other managers, as they circle the wagons.

Career progression is totally dependent on your manager. As is your review and salary/bonus.

Managers tend to promote their pals rather than those that are really doing the work. I've seen many people passed over for promotion, even though they are far more diligent and capable than those that get promoted.

Policy of replacing experienced engineers with graduates and expecting the team to train the new recruits and cover the extra workload, created by the void. 

They are getting rid of a lot of people at the moment.

review_title: Good for new hires but bad in the long run
job_title: Software Engineer in San Jose, CA
pros: Good company if you don't want to progress in life , not good for competitive people who want to learn and grow in their career and that is why most of the new hires leave quickly
cons:
Quality of engineers is degrading as interview process is a joke. Also a lot of under qualified interns get Full-time offers. Pay is sub-standard with no stock or bonuses, increment is very less. 

Too much politics within orgs and only different forms of flattery will give you a promotion rather than hard work.

Code Quality is very bad as most of the people try to go around the problem rather than actually fixing the problem. Most of the managers do not have a minimum technical understanding, less testing done when code is pushed to production and thus too many bugs and customer complaints. 

Company is trying too hard to show itself to be cool but in reality it is company of old people who have stayed so long that they don't understand the latest technologies. Their cloud is horrible, clearly losing business to competitors due to bad service

review_title: IBM Global Services -- Mismanaged, too short-sided, and too geographically-disbursed to be efficient
job_title: Delivery Project Executive in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros:
Benefits (health, vacation, etc.) are better than most companies, but don't expect perks.
401k matching is better than most other large tech companies.
IBM promotes a work/life balance, which most managers actively encourage.
Working from home is the de facto work arrangement for most non-technical job roles, including management.
cons:
There is zero budget for travel, training, additional software, and anything else outside your laptop and Lotus Notes.
Senior Management agrees to deals that generate losses in the near-term and then ask account managers to furlough contractors to meet profit goals for the quarter.  
Contractors are used far too much and are treated as simple commodities and not human beings.
Everyone works from home without video collaboration tools or a travel budget.  
No travel budget + country-wide teams = no team building.
Most employees never meet their managers face-to-face.  
A manager I hadn't met before conducted my exit interview and advised her college-aged child to avoid IBM.
Ethics battle between customer service and margin growth drives many good people out (including me).

review_title: Not the good old IBM anymore
pros: IBM has good brand awareness so as a salesperson it is easy to get customer meetings. The company has a broad portfolio of offerings so again as a salesperson you can meet with a lot of different types of customers and offer a multitude of solutions. IBM has a good benefits package, but HP has an even better one because they pay for a car for you to use. IBM offers good salaries but you cannot make commissions anymore due to 6 month quotas.
cons: The company has too many offerings and too many people. Too many people in management just sit in their homes and bother the in field sales reps. Because the company is so large the pricing for products and services is usually much larger than more nimble competitors. The morale at IBM is really bad right now. The sales culture at IBM has gotten horrible.

review_title: Geographically balanced, where US jobs grow wings.
pros: IBM is such a giant that working hard is really up to you, so even if merit-based raises are misaligned with reality, you can easily latch on to a decent salary without much effort.
cons: IBM has a very long chain mgmt chain, and an excess of red tape. Outsourcing of US jobs is happening constantly and the catastrophic results are treated with crowdsourcing, to no effect. Yet the senior mgmt in charge of this flawed strategy continue to move up the chain while the few left behind continue to mop up the mess being made.

review_title: Test operator  at the IBM Burlington Test Center
job_title: Test Lead Operator/Trainer in Burlington, VT
pros: Good work environment. When problems pop-up or developing stragies for processes, all hands on deck far as us operators engineers and management for the issue envolved. Standard works , 8-steps and Lean hashelp the process run a lot smother. Vacation and benifits are fairlly good.
cons: With talks of layoffs and being sold to Global the moral could be better. Because our division has not turn a profit. Pay raises and bonuses have been fewer and far in between. Because the stress level is way down from what it was for the main reason of lot smother running process all employees about all employees are more confidant and mature in their work process never the less  the evaluation one is rated to the peers in the department and the manager must come up with with a low end employee that gets put on probation and ether quick's or is let go.

review_title: Was good 20 years ago, but now....
pros:
- Multicultural workplace
- Access to new technologies (when you can find them)
- Interesting project
- Excellent first time job before hooping in the marketplace
- Excellent work/life balance (probably depends the job/location)
cons:
- Too much bureaucratic process for everything
- Salary stuck since several years
- Frequent change in process and organization, looks like nobody know where to go or how to do it, it's just going with the marketing flow and the buzzword of the month.
- Money and stock price first, customer seconds, employee last
- Better to be a manager if you want to survive, you can even be a manager of only 1 or 2 peoples and stay in place for years....
- No team spirit unless it benefit the individual, as you are ranked compared to your pair (even with the so called new system) everyone is an "adversary" around you.
- Unless you're a manger or in the top 2%, you will probably be fired before having any kind of real promotion

pros: The company sets great value upon education and each employee can broaden their knowledge easily, with the resources being available on every step online. Also, with integrity as the core I am additionally proud to be a member. Not only beginners are made aware of the essential principles, but everybody each year. IBMers have left a positive impact on me - everybody has been approachable, open, direct and warm. This also includes the recruitment process with the interviews being simple and pleasant. I hope to be able to stay in the community for a long time and develop accordingly.
cons: Since I joined the CIC at its very beginning, everything was new not only to me but also to the company and therefore it was necessary to be patient before the team could enter task specific training. However, it did not take long before the first team was organized into groups and a more concrete approach added where the new members could start focusing on their different roles.

pros:
- Good material: I have been given a 13in 2017 Macbook, at first it was a T460 ThinkPad
- Very good CE: reimboursement of 40% of your travel invoice (3 invoices for hotel + train + car rental)
- Bois-Colombe Site is very spacious and beautiful; I work at Ecully, which is much smaller but still  convenient.
- Very interesting mission: I work on Maximo, a big maintenance solution. There a many entities within IBM, you can try to ask for other subjects!
- A place to learn: here you will learn many new things, at least for me about IOT and very modern technologies
- My boss is very kind
- Flexible hours, a day of work starts at 9am and usually ends at 6pm but you can come and leave pretty much as you want, there is no presence control
- Possibility to work from home
cons:
- No cheque restaurant: I bring my own meal and so I'm not paid for my lunch. Only people who eat at the canteen have some reductions on their meals.
- Long process: Paper works should be more accelerated.
- Work environment should be renovated, it's getting a bit old and does not attract young employees.

review_title: A satisfactory internship with good pay.
job_title: Pre-Professional Software Engineer in Poughkeepsie, NY
pros:
There are a lot of bright people working at IBM. 
It's easy to get in contact with people to help you do what you need to do if your manager is any good.
The pay was good for an Junior/Senior-year internship.
cons:
I didn't like the corporate culture. Though the development process is relatively well-managed, you're dealing with a slow-moving behemoth.
Managers vary significantly in how much they micromanage. I ran into situations where I was micromanaged in a very negative way, and I've been in situations where I was not given nearly enough guidance even after asking for it.
Although it is intern work, it feels a bit thankless and meaningless because the projects I worked on seemed marginalized or on the verge of marginalization.

review_title: Good performance reviews don't guarantee continued employment.
pros: IBM has many convenient locations.  They allowed me to work from home whenever I wanted unless I had a "must attend in person" meeting.  They provided good benefits and matching 401(k) funds up to 7%.  They reimbursed employees for local travel.
cons:
The AIRRP.  The Annual Involuntary Resource Reduction Program.  Corporate profits drive all actions at IBM.  People are treated as commodities.  There's always another person who can take your place, and oh, yeah, they can pay them 20% of what they were paying you by shipping your job to India or Slovakia.        
IBM insists on using Lotus tools, such as Notes, Sametime and Symphony, which are poor imitations of Microsoft products.  By spending several years at IBM, you will lose touch with the rest of the world and when they lay you off, you won't have the skills and experience necessary to compete in the job market.

review_title: Tightly knit company but not for creatives.
job_title: Senior Project Manager in Toronto, ON
pros: IBM absolutely looks after its own. On large, multi-vendor projects particularly, the pressure can get pretty intense. IBMers who work in the same environment provide a tremendous bit of support for one another when things get tough. There's also some outstanding management who excel at looking out for their people.
cons: I found working at IBM I was constantly under pressure to change who I was. On one project where I achieved recognized results, I still routinely heard, "you don't belong here". On another, I got mixed messages from management every day - first they'd tell me to change my behaviour to become less creative and more corporate, but then in reviews tell me I should "just be myself". It was a very frustrating experience overall. I would absolutely not recommend IBM as a workplace for anyone who wants to develop creative solutions to problems.

pros: Nice work-life balance and lots of resources because of its large size.  Good place to start working ... they usually only hire new college graduates, anyway. Usually at the state of the art in terms of hardware design, but that is in decline.   Nice co-workers but the company pits everyone against everyone for performance reviews.
cons: If you going into IBM hardware, be careful.  Hardware earns money but unfortunately costs money.  The amount it earns is not as much as the top dogs think it should, so I would expect it to sell off or lay off more people in this area.  The company is top heavy, lots of senior people so you can get some early promotions, but then there are too many top dogs (due to experience) so you are stuck.  Its EDA tools are out dated --- at least it should try harder to use industry standard ones --- and that can be a problem if you ever leave.  Lots of regulations from the top down.

review_title: Once was proud of working at IBM - now it's a toxic environment of layoffs, benefit cuts, poor morale.
job_title: ZSystems Software Engineer in Poughkeepsie, NY
pros: With over 30 years experience here, about the only thing that still falls into the realm of PRO is decent flexibility for remote workers.
cons: In the last decade, internal education classes have gone from best of breed to non-existent.  Benefits have been cut across the board.  The PBC ranking has gone from a reasonable performance-based system to just a curved ranking system to build the next layoff candidate list.  Very few raises, little opportunity for internal advancement.  And finally, a petty cost management system that's reached the point where employees must not only supply their own office supplies, but their own monitors and keyboards too.  IBM provides one laptop and charger, which are now on a 4 year replacement cycle.

pros: IBM enjoys a tremendously positive brand recognition in the marketplace globally.  Here's the reason:  IBM truly offers more opportunities to impact the world. Interested in impacting healthcare?  Interested in making a difference in the lives of hundreds of thousands of people through a better strain of cocoa trees (think chocolate!), a better grain of rice (think of everyone whose daily staple food is rice), safer food supply chains, more efficient management of natural resources?  IBM is involved in all of these efforts!  We have high ethics, we offer acceptance of diversity in the workplace as well as diversity of thought in our projects.  I love the trust the company puts into our people. The focus on skills development is fantastic.  Our Values and Practices clearly lay out what is acceptable and what guides our actions.  Our clients trust and respect us for the way we unite to deliver excellent outcomes.
cons: Although we have a great flexible work environment, there is always so much to do, and it is so tempting to finish just one more item before logging off for the day!  :o)

review_title: The fabulous tech giant who doesn't know where to turn
pros: Great company history, the inspires every day. IBM Research is undoubtedly the best lab for IT. Whereever you turn in IT you will see people coming from IBM bringing enormous soft and hard skills from the Big Blue. Very good talent management, easy to transfer from one job to another, due to many hub like organization clusters. Wide variety of fields you can develop yourself let that be a subject matter expert or people management. Many bottom-up initiatives getting kicked-off. Great people to work with. Once an IBMer forever and IBMer.
cons: Average salary, low bonus, hence high attrition. Pyramid like hierarchy that hinders quick decision making and agile reaction to market forces. Lot of overhead blocking implementation of key actions and bottom-up initiatives.

pros:
Biggest benefit is work from home policy - undoubtedly the best in the industry,

Life is set if you have a good salary here..you can survive here without working in a project for many years , just make sure you get a  good project.

Work culture is good, quite friendly

No problems with reimbursements, travels etc processes are very well defined, if a resource is doing well he will be awarded.

Leaves not a problem

Deputation benefits not a problem

Very good for women employees married / non married
cons:
Lots of politics 
Most projects are run only on IBM's brand and IBM charges quite high to US Client plus IBM technical employees on an average are below the industry level of technical know how because IBM India has many projects on same old technologies.

A very slowly growing career can be expected due to the enormous number of employees and many under qualified technical employees.

IBM purely plays on reducing cost by hiring Bcom guys and training them internally and pushing them projects. Apparently, it lies to its clients when disclosing experience and qualification of resources.

pros:
IBMers hands down. I have always been amazed to find such bright, intelligent and resourceful people to work with. 
There were a lot of eyes on IBM having had a good quarter and the first big news that came out was regarding the expanded parental leave program. In the past I would have expected IBM to reinvest in research or growing a business line; this time however the first move was on how IBM reinvested in the workforce, it's employees. 
IBM recently expanded its parental leave program to 12 weeks, allowing parents (both moms and dads) to care for and share in the joys of the early childhood days. 
IBM also has a lot of diversity in job types that you can choose from and learn about a different part of the business allowing you the career options to innovate and learn; take it where you'd like to.
cons: Client facing roles involve a lot of travel and sometimes feel isolated from the DNA of IBM, you have to make a conscious choice to stay connected and networked within IBM. I learnt about the expanded parental leave program through a blog post; not top down from management.

pros:
I have worked with many companies in my 27 years of work experience, last 8 years has been the best years where I have been able to work for long hours and also spend time with my family. I have been able to take care of my body well which I live in . Work stress is for someone else not for me.
The best experience what I had was being a part of CSC.
How would you feel when someone offers you a month?
1.	To live with 20 best people, best in behavior, intellect, fun-loving, from across the world, sharing diverse cultures and language.
2.	Where you would be working on an assignment serving humanity with an organization who respects you, take care of you and support you.
3.	Have an opportunity to showcase your intellect with a free mind, no boss to ask you what you do?
4.	Learn innovative ways to work efficiently.
5.	Learn to be a leader and become one in the real university of world and not in class rooms.
6.	Get to see beautiful places with the best people around.
IBM provided me this opportunity as a part of CSC.
No company or university in the word can provide the experience and education which CSC gave me.
cons: Nothing to share as of now

pros: One of the amazing company I came across in my career  been with IBM for past 12 yrs gives me a thinking of fruitful years which I crossed and years to come. To be specific you are given freedom to take your own career   provided you have build the right network and right information in your ambit.
cons: One simple answer is IBM is an ocean where you may got lost easily.  So for advicd to freshers to intermediate folks get a tight hold of your trusted seniors in the org and take informed decisions.

pros: nothing, only work from home
cons: many, managers are selfish and thinks programmers are not working

review_title: It could be so much better with a bit of HR innovation
job_title: Consulting IT Specialist in London, England
pros:
The company has a huge number of great people. In general everyone helps one another in spite of any pointless control rules. When we want to get things done we just do it. The spirit that forms in teams and the global reach each team can have is very inspiring. 
Its the people who you learn to rely on that make it worth working there.
cons:
There is an old fashioned mentality one of measuring as an obsession. Very often the things measured and the processes that must be followed bear no resemblance to the value people are generating.
Too often the old fashioned management in control employees as resources comes into play. The reality is everyone works for the same company but these artificial power structures can seriously dent success for teams and individuals. If your first line manager does not like what you do, you may be able to still get things done bring value to clients etc, but you will get hit by the ridiculous personal business commitments review process that can be skewed any direction to fit a nominal bell curve distribution of performance required from up on high.

job_title: Staff Software Engineer in Cambridge, MA
pros: Given the vast amount of IBM brands, it isn't difficult to find a position of interest if you invest the time in creating connections across the company, and happen to have a management chain that supports personal growth of their employees.
cons:
The only reason IBM is doing well right now is because budgets are being slashed left and right, employee morale is at an all time low and management (if you're unlucky) can be quite condescending and non responsive to employee needs. Keeping the staff happy is nowhere on the priority list.
People are often expected to work extra long hours and weekends without any particular compensation, reward or acknowledgment. And the expectation isn't reflected in a request to come in but rather by assigning large amounts of work that don't actually make sense given a "normal" work day.

review_title: overall it is a good company
pros: Great company. Once you have the experience of working for IBM, it helps you find another job easily. Product is good, stable quality even the price is always higher than competitors. But one of the best things I have to say that IBM has lots of professional managers that willing to help employers grow and to be successful. I have had the opportunity to work with those managers that are open minded, understands employee's needs, concerns, and willing to listen. Overall, the working environment is pretty good, compare with other companies I worked before, and worked after I left IBM.
cons:
too much internal political, but it maybe unavoidable almost anywhere. 
IBM product is always famous for good quality, however, I could not understand why it is so hard for them to cut the cost, and when I worked for PC division, the one that sold to Lenovo later on, IBM could not effectively resolve issues from supply chain, and internal program error. As a leading IT organization, it looks difficult for IBM to resolve these issues, and it certainly hurt the company's reputation. I know they have tried, but it did not work well. I hope it gets better now.

review_title: Exciting technology and culture but not for Americans
job_title: Senior IT Specialist in Seattle, WA
pros:
The rate of adoption of collaboration tools internally ( blogs, Lotus Connections , wikis ) has been astonishing and has led to an exciting work culture.
IBM is working on a lot of exciting technologies in a variety of markets.
Ability to work from home is a huge plus
cons: One of the biggest issues at IBM is the insistence on having a "face to face" role if your position is to remain in the US or Europe.  The emphasis of on off-shoring positions to BRIC countries has been a multi-year effort.  Procurement, HR, payroll, as well as 1st, 2nd, and now 3rd line support are all being or have been moved to lower labor-cost countries.  The message is clear that if you want to have a long tenure in a 1st world country with IBM, you need to be in a direct customer-contact role (e.g. sales, consulting ) otherwise it can be done from a variety of other locations...

review_title: Great place to work, but you have to know how to play the politics game
pros: You can go as far as you want at IBM.  There are so many opportunities to get recognized from a technical standpoint that don't move through your management chain, so nobody can take credit for your work.  IBM rewards employees for submitting patents, for presenting ideas that make sense, etc.
cons: You have to know how to play the politics game.  Managers can play favorites, and make sure those favorites are being promoted, getting interesting work assignments, etc.  Sometimes the only solution is to punt and look for opportunity under another management chain.  Also, IBM still has the "Employee for Life" attitude, and think nothing of keeping an employee at an entry-level position for 5 or more years, and at a staff position for the rest of their careers.  In a lot of technology based companies, employees do not stick around 5 years.

review_title: The breadth of experience and quality of people in research overshadowed any negatives
pros: During my time at IBM I was able to work with some of the smartest and most passionate people in the industry.  IBM commands and audience even when they don't have a market position with their products.  I was at the table with CEO's, CIO's, Industry leaders and even heads of state.
cons: There were several areas within IBM that focused on sales and operational metrics that were not accurate.   Several divisions in IBM we so focused on their numbers that they forgot how to provide a real solution that could be implemented without engaging an Non-IBM services partner.

review_title: Good workers, very bad executive management.
job_title: Software Engineer in San Jose, CA
pros: A lot of good, helpful workers. Decent salary. Flexible work schedule.
cons:
Working 60+ hours a week not uncommon, including weekends, just to keep up with the work. Performance ratings are given out on a curve. So, even if you are in an area with a lot of high performers, only a small percentage are allowed to get high ratings and good performers will get low ratings. Those that get the lower ratings are candidates for being laid off.
Executives are focused on EPS and stock prices - likely due to the fact that a lot of their salary is in stock bonuses. Instead of focusing on delivering high-quality products and satisfying their customers to increase revenue, they rely on cutting expenses, including lay-offs. The employees are fearful of the next round of lay-offs, which occur more and more frequently. There is no longer respect for the employees by the executives like there used to be.

pros:
Will give you experience beyond what anyone else will provide and thereby accelerate your career. 

Mature processes, work with some brilliant people, push you to new limits
cons:
Low wage for role performed, even government pays more

Dont want u there for more than 5 years, have an exit plan.

Have one way of doing things and other employers wont want you if you have been there too long

Bad name with other employers, employees often burnt out and exploited, become damaged goods.  Have an exit plan!!

Terrible culture of working 50 hr weeks, dont believe for 1 sec you will work 37.5hrs!!  I workwd 16 hour days m-f for 6 months once.

No bonus, no rewards, nonpayrises.  I was a hr mgr, dont believe the 12% bonus crap, no mgr was allowed to give more than 5% EVER!  And most were 1-3% and thats when people were killing themselves for the glorious company.  

This is a bad place to work, but it will make you stronger.  Have a 2 year plan, wxit by 3 - its what they want anyway!!

review_title: A great company to grow your career
job_title: Cloud Labs Delivery Manager in Ciudad de Mexico
pros:
I have worked for IBM 18 years. I have seen a lot of people go from this company to others in the industry (Microsoft, Oracle, SAP, and others) and the most common thing they miss about IBM is how much material to grow internally your skills is available. 
Some other people miss the "good vibe", or the ethical principles by what we are guided... (and this last part is no exageration, I have seen directly how top and executive management prefer to lose on a deal rather than winning it unethically. A big differentiator to some other companies in the industry.
cons: IBM is a BIG company. And I mean BIIIG. Decisions, specially those that involve finance can take a lot of time, and work from the people involved. On the same note, career projection is also a long term goal. Planning your career in terms of the next 5 years is not uncommon, and is also a key difference, specially for younger employees.

job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Boston, MA
pros: Amazing colleagues, good benefits, access to resources
cons: Terrible, extremely short-sighted management, micro-managed work environment

pros: Large company, likely to stay in business.  Unfortunately, there is no stability or security; there appears to be a constant drive to exploit employees by making non-professionals exempt, reducing vacations, and benefits.  Exempt folks are required to work 10% overtime.  Managers are kept away from their employees -- it is much less stressful to lay someone off if you have never met.  Even "teams" are assembled from distant locations, creates less emotion when someone is "disappeared".  There is no company education -- early in the year, there is no budget; later in the year, there is no time available.  Not the great company IBM once was; Sam sets the tone.
cons: Working at IBM is like playing roulette.  Whether you have a job day-to-day is like spinning a wheel; your continued employment has nothing to do with your abilities or competence.  I met my last manager face to face for the first time on the day I left the company.  I had worked for her for two years.

review_title: Good company, but senior managers REALLY need to retire.
job_title: Advisory Project Manager in Boulder, CO
pros: Pay is good, so are benefits despite the "take aways" from the employees with 20+ years.  It looks great on your resume, and you get plenty of process experience.  Most of the people are pretty smart.
cons: My group is under the CFO, but not a finance function.  Our operations are hampered by the constant finance focus with little regard for the health of the operations until something "breaks."  There are a large number of processes to adhere to, and many people are trying to create their own so they can claim it.  They claim to only hire the "best of the best," but then you get in and now you have to become the best of the best of the best.

review_title: IBM is no longer loyal to employees they way it used to be.
job_title: Administrative Analyst in Long Beach, CA
pros: IBM contributions into 401k and health benefits are good.  The pay for most jobs is a little higher than other companies - that is, whenever they decide to "honor" us with a raise (which unfortunately hasn't been consistent).  There are many IBM Facilities and Project Offices all over the world.
cons: Sending work overseas and laying off their "family" or bringing people in from other countries who take the jobs away from United States citizens.  They think they will save money with paying people from other countries lower salaries, but there have been too many problems with communication barriers and time differences.  In the long run, I believe there are more problems than solutions.  There have also been too many times when IBM has said we had a good year, but then tell us we did not do well enough to warrant giving us raises.

review_title: IBM - Nice place to stay but I wouldn't want to live there.
job_title: Advisory IT Specialist in Halifax, NS
pros: The flexible work hours and work-from-home options are great.  The breadth of knowledge and resources is almost unlimited.  The social networking tools are par to none.
cons: It is very difficult to change jobs.  And job advancement is quite difficult as well.  Billable utilization targets increase every year and they are already to the point where you are required to work more than 40 hrs/week to meet the target.  On top of that there are hours and hours of work that is not billable that you are required to do for self-evaluation at least 2 - 3 times per year.

job_title: Senior Administrative Assistant in Campinas, São Paulo
pros: Such a huge company so the possibilities you have to develop yourself are big.
cons: Too big. It's hard to be seen. Especially if working at CSO, the salaries are really different from the other ones known at IBM. Also , to get a promotion to a higher band, you must hardwork a lot for 100 or 200 reais more (50 to 100 USD). There are cases where the person was promoted and got only 50 reais (25 USD) as salary plus food card with 150 reais (75 USD) credit. Also it's really bad for all the CSO new employees to be employed with a 44hours week contract (it means they work 40 and don't get any payment for the first 14 overtime hours worked, which is very very bad and unfair. About the retirement plan, IBM used to co-parcipate with 3% + 50% of the employees contribuition, limited to 5%, which means that if the employee pays 10% or his/her salary, IBM used to pay 8% more to a fund. Now, all the new employees get only 1% from IBM. Nothing else. CSO seems to be different from the whole IBM.

review_title: A stable job through two recessions
job_title: Research Staff Member in Hawthorne, NY
pros: I joined in the late 90s - straight out of college after completing my PhD. While the research divisions in other companies fell apart, IBM continues to survive. My salary has doubled over a decade and I have been promoted while retaining a research scientist role -- all while going through 2 recessions. I cant complain.
cons: Finding a groove where you can really make a difference to the company (and hence further your career) is difficult. Partly because it is a large organization with a large bureaucracy - although sometimes you get the feeling that sr management could do better. Recently (last 3-4 years) the US research division has been shrinking - where as the China and India labs are growing at a torrid pace. This doesn't make for a pleasant work environment - with people doing weird things to justify their value to the company. The only long term survival/growth option for me is to get into a pure management role - which I don't much like doing.

job_title: Lead Technical Writer & IT Specialist in Salisbury, England
pros:
Excellent 1st line managers who really care about their people.
IBM Encourages movement across teams and projects, which keep skills and motivation fresh.
Flexible working hours, and very open-minded and supportive about work/life balance.
I joined for long-term stability - which I got, but I believe times have been tougher since I left.
cons:
Annual peer reviews are overly beaurocratic and often a bit insulting - IBM seems to promote the team environment, but come annual assessment everyone is pitched against each other. I was even once told "you've had a great year, but I've got mark you as unsatisfactory, as I've got to draw the line somewhere".
Tough times have seen a slash in all budgets, so very little in the way of rewards and off site team building. No education budget is tempered by highly skilled workforce doing skill shares.
Once you get beyond the 1st line of management you often hit a wall of egos. In a long spell, I wasn't always impressed with 2nd line managers and above due to poor lines of communication, and the directors of engineering tended to throw their weight around unneccessarily.
The work isn't always shared equally across teams - I noticed that often 90% of the work done is by 10% of the people.

review_title: Dead end place to work. avoid
pros: I had some friends there. Oh and I no longer work there ;-)
cons:
salary below market rate. I had a string of unhelpful,  ineffective,  self interested managers, all who would try to convince you  you were only worth that. No training,  no promotional opportunities. Really felt disrespected all the time. Very difficult to move around. dank depressing office, converted factory so no natural light, in the middle of nowhere.  Poor public transport,  and a long drive.  Awful overpriced canteen. In short Ibm are cheap, with people and facilities.  Impossible to keep your dignity and get promoted. A final insult was an annual Christmas dinner at this Fridays, budget per head under a tenner. And we were forced to attend! 

I'm happy to say I no longer work there,  I get annual reviews,  bonuses  I work with much smarter less smug people. I am treated with much more respect. 

I did get some experience in the area I wanted but only when I think it was clear I was ready to walk out the door.  
In summary skip it completely.  Don't even apply. Especially when you see the ceo sucking up to a bigot, to boost her shares.

review_title: Was okay for a bit. Time to move on
pros: Benefits are decent for me. (Not sure about families) 401K Match is also a positive, just have to wait until the end of the year to see it. Colleagues are fantastic. Flexible schedule to a degree.
cons: Management for my current project is pathetic, they all totally lack any sort of people skills.  Compensation is not up to par. In my opinion IBM does not pay anywhere close to competitively compared to other companies. As many other reviewers have said raises are near non-existent. My last couple of raises of been 1-2% which does not even cover cost of living increases. GBS 98%  billable utilization target is extremely high. (around 40 hours of vacation, before extra hours are needed to be worked to make up for time-off.  Friends who work for the competition have utilization targets around 85%.  They get to work from home too.

review_title: YES for work-life balance, NO for growth and appreciation
pros:
work-life balance - depending on the role and manager, might have access to up to 100% of home office 
access to some education 
pretty good opportunities for lateral moves
lately good choice of laptops- mac, windows or unix os
no pressure to work overtimes
cons:
very hard to get a salary increase, which even if you do, will be strictly limited to certain percentage and will not happen more often than once every few years
due to the matrixed organization your people manager often has no real idea about your performance and job whatsoever 
fairly low morale in the company due to salaries lower then market level, people are always looking to opportunities outside the company
high management turnover - often people on managerial positions are weak leaders
do not expect any benefits - your monthly salary will be it

review_title: Nobody cares, all about unachievable billable rate
job_title: Senior Managing Consultant in Bethesda, MD
pros: Inclusive, welcoming, good legacy / history
cons: No one cares, no sense of team, old technology (Lotus Notes?!), not agile, inflexible leadership

pros:
Work-life balance. In a generic organisation, its a term used to 'mimic' an attempt at the employer being a friend of the employee. At IBM on the other hand, its a life-style. It is truly etched into everyone psyche that an employee comes first, everything else follows. This is a truly great phenomenon that allows for for the employee to respect and love the company, as it in return gives you the creative freedom as well as one which lets you work when you want and where you want.

A lot of people start running after $ compensation, without realising that in order to get those dollars/pesos/rubles, one must work 60-70 hour weeks. Where as with IBM, a company that truly respects your time and worth, allows you to schedule your time around work, thus giving you a much more flexible lifestyle.
cons: Has an extreme bureaucratic feel to it, as there are many hoops that must be gone through to achieve anything. Run a lot like a governments. The problem is with that this applies a lot to promotions. If he ain't dead, we don't replace him - doesn't matte if he's incompetent.

review_title: DON"T work for IBM Global Services
job_title: Adivsary Software Engineer in Raleigh, NC
pros:
I can't think of a best reason to work for IBM Global Services, unless you consider having your job shipped over to India a good reason to work.
The pay is good, the benefits are good, provided you don't get laid off after you train your replacement in India.
cons:
Getting rid of senior people for inexperienced people in India, then the people that are left, having to train the India folks, so the U.S base work force can be downsized even more.  Then taking heat because projects are late or have a lot of bugs in them.
management is so focused on meeting next qtr that they are getting rid of good quality people at all levels and replacing them with inexperienced peopjle in India, then woundering why projects get behind.  The middle management are only following orders of Senior management.
the last few years, the focus on education has gone down hill unless it can be billed directly to a customer account. Advancement is becoming much harder in the U.S as jobs are being sent to India, as I've stated many times.

review_title: Time to expose Big Blue as a Big Fraud.
pros: The benefits and perceived respect for IBM in the marketplace.
cons: Unless you reside in the ivory tower in Armonk, you are just a serial # to this company.  Management is a joke. They are not respected, because generally speaking, most of them are incompetent.  They rely on their team to make them look good, so when it comes time for recognition, they have no problem accepting it for themselves, rather than passing it on to those who "truly" deserve it.  The PBC rating system (yearly review) is a joke, it is a luck of the draw exercise.  I have found that in 10 years with the company, it seems we spend more time trying to justify our employment by making sure our powerpoint presentations look pretty and also that the data presented to executives is as "accurate as possible".  Employee morale is horrible.  It has become a depressing company to work for.

review_title: Thrilling at first, Monotonous over the years
pros:
1. Its as entrepreneurial as you make it to be.  If you are the entrepreneurial  type, then you are already looking to being on your own, within IBM.  If you are not entrepreneurial, be prepared to ask questions and get vague responses. 
2. Colleagues / Peers across Towers are supportive, implying IBM-work-life is universal  regardless of Tower.
cons:
1. Base Compensation - your market intelli  and what your manager tell you are not compatible.  So where else is this not the case.
 2. Additional Comp - Seek and Read the rules carefully.  IBM is not giving $$ away.  2012 is perceived as an Employers Market.  
3. at companies the size of IBM you work within Policy and Procedures, Approval Limits, etc.   If you are entrepreneurial, you will chase down the approval routes and document each one on the road to getting things done.  If you are not entrepreneurial you will find the IBM Policy and Procedures, Approval Limits, a great Selective buffer to actually NOT getting anything done.

review_title: Good, stable and slow to take decisions
job_title: Advisory Software Engineer in São Paulo, São Paulo
pros: I salary is around the average. Company allows you to grow if you work to it. Lots of good things in IT happens at IBM, mainly cloud, mobile, database, etc. It is definitely a place to stay n touch with very recent technologies. Benefits are good too. Definitely Home Office is a major benefit to me. It is easy to find experts for any IT area, like people that wrote the books you read at school work for IBM. This is awesome !!!
cons: Due to its big size, there are tons of process even for small things. You are required to run into education courses not related to your day to day job. Even though there is space to grow, things are VERY slow. Appraisal process is like a pain in the and the results are not always clear.

review_title: Great potential and technology, does not care about greatest asset: people
job_title: Human Resources in New York, NY
pros: Technology. Acquisition and Divestiture strategy. Smart approach to M&A. R&D capability is beyond compare. Flexible and remote working support. Global breadth and depth. Hard working employees. I think Ginni Rometty's strategy is the right one and might eventually lead to top line revenue growth, but if IBM doesn't start treating employees better, it won't matter.
cons: Extremely arrogant. Senior executives live different (far better) lives than on-the-ground employees and are ridiculously out of touch. The anytime, anywhere, all the time, wherever you are, even if you are on holiday workplace. Lack of reward. A culture of managing up and brownnosing. Don't really want to hear results from engagement surveys. Indignant that employees don't recommend working at IBM. Finance dominated culture. Maniacal focus on cost cutting, non-stop Resource Actions, blaming employees for lack of success in IBM strategy. Hierarchical top down culture.

job_title: Consultant, Global Business Services in London, England
pros:
Opportunity to travel (although not always to glamorous locations)
High amount of flexibility between roles and ability to try different things.
Ability to work from home some times.
cons:
Management (and in fact all employees) are overworked so non-essential activities like organizing team events, training and so on are often overlooked.
Career development is left entirely to the employees who are told 'you are in control of your path'. I think that this is just laziness from management who really need to do more to guide and develop employees, especially ones that are new to the industry and don't understand the range of opportunities available, 
Expectation to travel away from home and stay in a hotel every week Monday to Thursday.
Long hours (50 hour week is completely normal and 60 hour week is not uncommon) and people eat lunch at their desk rather than take a proper lunch break.
IBM is not selling enough work, so there are not enough interesting projects, so the talented managers have left / are leaving, therefore the projects get in to problems due to weak leadership. This means that junior employees learn mostly from their own mistakes rather than good instructions from experienced managers, have to work really hard to grind out mediocre results, and do not get good job satisfaction from making clients happy.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros:
-- The people you work with are some of the smartest and most experienced in the industry.

-- Great mentorship opportunities from senior engineers.

-- People are very dedicated and work hard.

-- Generally, good team atmosphere and you learn a lot.
cons:
-- Management is completely hit or miss. My experience on one team was quite positive, my experience on another team was horrible.

-- Depending on the managements, the project/product can either succeed or totally fall on its face. The engineers will be blamed in any negative outcome. 

-- Bad management do not take responsibility and blame everyone for missed deadlines. Be very careful switching teams and talk to employees who are currently there and pull honest feedback out of them before making the switch.

job_title: Vice President Engineering in New York, NY
pros:
IBM has a strong career path for technical people. You can get a mentor who really cares about you and help you to plan your career over the next 10 years.
IBM really cares about Making it easy for people with diverse backgrounds to work together without discrimination. I’m not going to say that women have it perfect out here, but management makes an active effort to promote women and this creates an atmosphere which is more conducive to collaboration than any I have seen elsewhere. Discrimination against Asians is nonexistent, or at least not significant enough for me to detect.
People will go out of their way to help you.
There is a wealth of opportunities to progress at any time. You need to ensure that you are aligned with the company goals rather than just what your manager is asking you to do.
cons: The biggest problem at working at IBM is to take an idea and to have world-class impact. It’s relatively easy to have any impact at the scale off one customer or even one line of business but to create a product that’s going to revolutionize the world is difficult.

pros:

job_title: Senior Product Manager in Austin, TX
pros: IBM has tremendous access to markets and customers.  It has robust lines of business across a wide area of IT and consulting, making it possible to spend an entire career (or two) within its boundaries.  IBM enjoys a solid, world-class brand and is instantly recognizable.  For those that are passionate about technology, and are good communicators, this is a great place to work.
cons: It is a huge place dominated by bureaucracy, office politics and lack of transparency from management.  There is almost too much technology -- through acquisitions, legacy and research, not to speak of assets developed by IBM services, it has created an unwieldy and vast number of products, technologies and components that make it difficult to move quickly.  What makes it frustrating is that there is innovation happening but IBM makes it difficult to take its own assets to market effectively

review_title: """IBM""" does it really stand for I've Been Mugged???
job_title: Senior Systems CE in London, England
pros:
IBM Support structures are second to none. 
Cutting edge technologies, and innovations.
cons:
Lack of motivation from staff who are seeing nothing in the way of pay rises. Effectively having to take an inflation rate pay cut, year on year. 
A review system that concentrates on performace metrics which are outdated, and inefectual, meaning that the people who get on with management get the best reviews, whilst those that actually DO the work are often not rewarded at all.

pros:

Lots of rooms to switch jobs within the company if you're not happy with your current one.
cons:

Hard to get around unless you have a car. Traffic is really bad during rush hour.
Too many useless meetings (but this really depends on the team you're on).

review_title: It is not a so-called respectable company at all.

Employee has to pay for any loss of  IBM and its partner but has no right to get compensation from IBM and its partner even they causes employee's damage.

review_title: Work at IBM - Stability or Stagnation
job_title: Software Quality Assurance Engineer in Dublin, Dublin
pros:

Flexibility and Working from Home - can work remotely, that gives great flexibility (although that is becoming more and more common for IT companies)
cons:
No Grow - I'd rate it 2 out of 10 in terms of carrier opportunities, once you're there it is very likely that you'll be finding yourself at exactly the same level in terms of position and salary in 5-6 years (well salary may increase a bit, but less than inflation)

review_title: Ibm security services will reach 1 billion this year with a 80% annual growth rate

pros:

Access to world-class technology and solutions.

review_title: A business that spends more time fighting internally of who is responsible for what than actually accomplishing work.
job_title: Windows Systems Engineer in Columbia, MO
pros: The overtime was nice when it was available.
cons:
There are yearly ratings for each person in each team. Each team has a bell curve. You can be a hair lower in experience or progress compared to your peers and end up being graded poorly. Which results in no bonus. This is a very unfair system.

Depending on what account you work on, you could be applied to no overtime, oncall rotation, and in the cross fire between teams. Again, there is more arguing of who does what and whose problem it is than actually going ahead and doing the work. Just about every little adjustment requires a change that can take anywhere between 24 hours to a week to be approved before you can do said change.

Moving up in the company can also be very difficult. At the time I came in and later laid off, openings on my account were non-existent. Those with experience mostly held their jobs.

Training was non-existent and you learned as you went.

Last, the company seems to be laying off people at random. Regardless of how much you worked or not. You can have a really good or average PBC and still be laid off.

pros:
Exposure to mixed hierarchy and functional teams, truly global organization structure, knowledge to industry standards and serious professionals (among the senior management) to learn from. 

Offices in Central/Easter Europe are getting bigger, more opportunities to come in that area. Might be a good time to start working for IBM, which is also growing on its new key business areas.
cons:
IBM working environment can vary a lot, depending on which country you work in. Our colleagues in Germany, Nordic countries and UK are way more efficient and always get things done, while in Slovakia and other Central/Eastern Euopean countries there are still many organizational issues, which I hope are going to be removed in the near future. The salary is quite low, but there are many opportunities to look around in other departments to build your career.  

Processes are often broken down to very tiny bits, so it can be hard to get the big picture or the overall sense of your work.

pros:
Work life balance
