cons:
Pathetic Indian top management. Most of them are in Retiring age and they don't give a damn about company or its employees. They are more worried about their salary and benefits. In a nutshell they just want to survive in the organization 
  IBM is a technical company and  managers are clueless of technology. Imagine how effective can they be. Managers pride themselves on not being technical and will run away from any opportunity to do anything close to technical
  Top management adept at working in Excel and nothing much else. They don't have any clue about strategy, Business, technology any skill which is required for Software technology company
  They offer bonus (Bogus bonus) in compensation. Despite being a top rater you hardly get 15 percent of it
  Focus is more on utilization than the placing right skills  at right places. 
  No salary hikes. I have been working in IBM for more than 5 years and Iam top rater for last 4 years.. I get hike around 1 to 2 percent every year

review_title: Not recommend, no stability, unclear future
pros: Great flexibility in managing your own time. Decent IT support for desktop and mobility. Very good medical and retirement benefits for long term employees but less so for new hires.
cons:
Once IBM focused on markets where it could hold a leadership share. Now... it's unclear what markets and products matter to IBM. This year has been topsy turvy in the hardware business and the management style has become harsh. With continuous layoffs and cutbacks morale is quite low. Pay for sales is erratic. There isn't much positive to say about the current environment. Maybe it will change? Clients are confused by the ongoing disruption in relationships with IBM sales and support. The company has experienced 18 consecutive quarters of reduced revenue and profit. How long can this continue?

The current HR plan is to cut cost driving experienced sales and technical staff out through layoffs. There are no clear internal opportunities for promotion or growth as only external hires will be considered for job postings.  

IBM has become an unusual place.

review_title: Money is good, but toxic environment
pros: IBM pays a good base salary.  Medical coverage especially for prescriptions is excellent.
cons:
No long term structure
Sales plans are changed every half. What you sell changes, who you sell to changes.
They have a calculation that they use to determine if you are succeeding in sales or not. What it doesn't take into account is that there is a 12-18 month sales cycle. When your territory and clients change every 6 months... and it takes two months to get the details to you... you are expected to achieve in 4 mo what it takes 18 to do. The only way you luck out is if previous sales reps have gotten something to the finish line and you capitalize on it. Their calculation for what it looks like to "succeed and have the necessary skills" changes as well. So you never know in six months if you'll have a job or not.

review_title: You need to be one of the boys !
pros: IBM looks good on the resume.  They do have a lot of big name customers and you will learn to work in a very large matrix organization.  The use of home offices and mobile offices is a great concept.  Good training in both products and selling.   Also IBM has a very large software offering- so you can to what suites you best.
cons: You need to be one of the boys or you are not going anywhere !   To many people doing the same job -  Be careful layoffs have to be coming.  It is not your fathers IBM - management is only concerned about making quarterly numbers- and making their bonus.  While most of the sales people are not making their numbers.

job_title: Program Manager in San Francisco, CA
pros: As a "Tier 1" employee, I was given a sweet retention package.  The benefits are pretty good - including discounts on all sorts of services (AT&T phone bill, hotel stays, etc).  IBM also practices "workforce flexibility" so I can work from home every single day.
cons: It's an isolating existence.  All of the things you expect about IBM are true - tons of bureaucracy, tons of politics - a "matrixed" organization which means you have more than one boss and roles are not clear.  There's also a big difference between those IBMers who are "career" and those who are acquired.  Despite the years of experience I brought when I was acquired, I still remain in a pretty junior role - even though I get paid 30% more than my peers based on my many years of experience (i guess getting paid well isn't a con, but it is when my responsibilities are so small compared to what I did prior to the acquisition).

review_title: Used to be awesome, but is no longer investing in innovation and is coasting on it's historical record
pros:
By and large, fantastic co-workers.    Some wonderful projects, technically very interesting.  Development environment is a smoothly oiled machine that can be highly productive.
Fellow IBMers, by and large, very supportive when their management doesn't stop them.
cons: Mediocre middle-managers.  Some major, expensive technical decisions made to advance personal careers at the expense of the company.   If you are not in a 'hot' area (currently anything with 'analytics' in the title) then it's challenging to get funding, and without money life becomes grim, even if the area is profitable or essential for other areas.  In the last 8 years it has increasingly felt like the Soviet Union, where fear becomes a primary motivational tool.  Managers are easily fooled by ambitious employees.  Your time is better spent working on some minor (and typically low-value) project that helps the manager than actually improving the product, or fixing customer problems.

review_title: Decent entry level role for those with no prior experience, but look to move on quickly
pros: Decent but declining company brand to put on a resume for future job searches. Great opportunity to develop ping pong and foosball skills. Able to take long lunches and leave early for the day without anyone noticing. Company sponsored events are fun, including baseball games and trips to Minneapolis. Good stepping stone to finding a better job in the cities.
cons: Finance is drastically underpaid compared to other companies. Intense boredom is common. Some days I go the entire day without doing any work at all. If you give the impression that you have improved your role and eliminated work, you are rewarded with more responsibility and work added to your role with no additional pay increase. New hires are trained by the person who had the role previously, if the previous worker is already gone, you are in trouble.  They used to order pizza for quarter close but the expense was hurting IBM's earnings, so they cut that out. They sell the dream of being promoted to the New York location, but that rarely materializes.

review_title: Good Company if you can handle the Bureaucracy
job_title: Brand Portfolio Seller in Chicago, IL
pros:
Many smart people at IBM.  Especially in the R&D and product management organizations.  
Global reach.  Great name recognition.
Great benefits including 401K matching.
Opportunities for younger staff members to learn and grow from more seasoned veterans.
cons:
100% Self-service culture.  No administrative support.  Must learn complex processes on your own via trial and error.
Constant change to account lists, product mix, and reporting structures makes continuity challenging.
Some products are great, market-leading and cutting edge.  Others are terribly stale and based on old technology.
Size of organization creates many highly complex processes for everything.  Even the simplest of tasks often seem terribly complex and take an inordinate amount of time.  
For example, getting a quote approved with special terms to go through a channel partner can be a 1-2 week process.  3 business days if you expedite and invest hours walking it through the approval process.

review_title: Come to IBM to change the world!
pros: IBM is an exciting place these days as it transforms in many ways to address  market challenges. From cloud computing, to AI, to quantum computing or blockchain, there is no technology that you can't touch and make an  impact on. The people come from all backgrounds and experiences, with IBM embracing diversity. You can always reach out to people for help and guidance and at the same time senior people have an opportunity to mentor others. I've worked here for 5 years and have seen the transformation from a traditional IT company to an exciting place for innovation and collaboration. Its definitely one of the few companies that can have a impact on society and the world.
cons: As with any large organization, you have to be patient with some of the bureaucracy. Being a global company there are rules and regulations it has to conform to, which can seem to slow down some initiatives. But management seems committed to streamlining things.

review_title: Stay far far away! Toxic culture, lack of accountability, no company direction.
pros: Higher level positions supposedly pay very well, but I was not exposed to that.
cons: The corporate culture isn't just toxic, it's nonexistent. At IBM, you are expected to put your head down and do your work, there is no collaboration. I received next to no training, and was expected to succeed immediately. If you don't, it's your own fault. I was a part of the Watson Health business unit, which is a total sinking ship. As many progressive companies move towards flexible work environments, IBM is moving further from it. In my 9 months in this position, I never once had any type of 1:1 or coaching from my manager to discuss performance, much less career goals. There is constant turnover for all of the aforementioned reasons, and as such, I had 4 different managers in my 9 month tenure. I can not stress enough, stay far far away. I regret to even give IBM 1 star.

pros: Friday flex days, planned events by the COE, 401K match, having IBM on your resume, working with 350 other 20 year olds
cons: Being controlled by 3 different contradicting forces, low low pay, not much of a bonus, constantly being inundated with IBM propaganda, knowing that no matter how hard you work, you will get the same ratting. Unless your good at sucking up, you won't find much progression here. Management stresses having experience in all different roles, and then five seconds later will tell you how important it is to stay in the same job role for 2 years, this tends to go along with their standard practice of contradicting themselves and not having the intelligence to realize it.

pros:
- Excellent place to learn                                                                                                                                                  
- Superb work life balance
- Explore new opportunity within the organisation
- Amazing brand value
cons:
- huge disparity in compensation 
- defunct HR organisation , all power rest with people manager and his wimps and fancies
- Least bother about "human resources"

review_title: Work you hard, but pay relatively well in Canada
pros:
Nice facilities including personal work area with doors. Nice common area, and in the suburb so no need to drive download to get to work and pay for expensive parking. There's an onsite gym with free class. 

The company is big and offer somewhat stable employment opportunity. There's a big student internship program that offers way to get extra help and also allow you to look for next generation talent for hire.
cons:
It's such a big organization that it makes you feel like you are only a part of something huge.
It's hard to see your impact on the business and there are way too many processes, or "way to do things" that make innovation and simplification difficult. There's also slow pace for compensation increase and career advancement, if you want to have a quick in your career. It's not likely to happen here.

review_title: IBM is taking cost cutting to an extreme
job_title: Technical Sales in New York, NY
pros: Lots of smart people.  Great technologies.  Plenty of opportunities to do a lot of different things in your career (though you need to be very motivated to do this).
cons: From the inside, it feels like the company is going out of business.  Cost cutting is being taken to an extreme, from everything as simple as office supplies to something more complex like commissions.  Every team meeting was about finding new opportunities and closing business.  "Everybody sells" is the corporate mantra.  There's a stated goal to get EPS to $20 by 2015, doing so is going to hurt IBM (there are plenty of articles about this, just Google for it).  This is not your father's IBM, the company has changed significantly over the past several years.

review_title: After you have enough project experience, get the hell out of IBM consulting
pros: Good project experience and exposure. This is the only good thing about IBM. the project exposure was quite good if you are just starting out. If you already have some experience and have certain expectation of your career path and compensation, do not bother at all. So, get the hell out as soon as you feel you can survive outside this sweatshop in the real world.
cons: Can not believe how incompetent, ignorant and mean many project leads, project managers and managers are. You have to work well over 100 hours a week, you are expected to do yours, and your managers, and your leads' work, and the clients are lied to by management and project leads all the time so you are stuck in the middle trying to implement a non-sense solution for clients

review_title: Low moral and not getting any better
pros: Great potential for the future and a lot of great ideas being talked about that could make a very bright future.
cons: Currently too focused on financials and not growing talent, skills, retention, and reassurance of the overall company direction. The top technical resources are being scooped up by other companies by the hour. The company attempt to pretend they are providing education is extremely too focused on current highlighted technologies, but what the company forgets is that even the latest and greatest direction, like Cloud, requires many other skills underneath to be able to provide and improve on that give area.

review_title: There are a lot of opportunities and benefits at IBM, though at times certain decision makers perplex you
job_title: Senior Software Product Manager in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Always other opportunities available within the company as you feel it's time for a change, and they recognize dedication and hard work with retention. IBM has a list of even some hidden benefits that have provided an overall package that's very good. The flexibility to work from home is big a financial and a social benefit.
cons: Salary growth is difficult when with the company for a long period of time. Some careful treading through politics and privilege is sometimes necessary, and occasionally some of the bloat in bureaucracy hinders your ability to get things done efficiently or in a timely manner for your clients.

review_title: One of the latest places to do real RESEARCH
job_title: Research Staff Member in Yorktown Heights, NY
pros:
- Research environment, like academia. You finish the PhD and you continue to do what you like most: doing research but getting payed properly!
- Total flexibility
- Open minded environment
- Trust  (they trust you. 100% confidence in you).
cons:
- Sometimes, you are on your own. You have to search for interesting projects and 'sell' them to the other peers. But, isn't that research?
- Lots of bright minds but sometime you feel a 'generational' barriers... You might be discussing with >65yo man who still does research with their own (sometime outdated) methods. Nevertheless, I've to admit that fundamental thinking is much better in these people w.r.t new millenials. We are more focused to the 'trial&error' approach looking for solution because technology is fast nowadays, but they THINK, study and analyze the problem first, before investing in implementation: 99% of the time, they are right. You can learn a lot from them... but it is time-consuming.
- IBM does not provide the great benefits (free meals, massages, etc.) that new young companies are providing to their employees.

pros: Not much to write home about except that there are some very talented people at IBM. Some groups still allow WFH. I have worked here for 20+ years so there must have been something good but hard to quantify.
cons: Good for top executives and 2% employees. Others are just going through the motions. No clear direction. Even the much touted Watson is bleeding money. Mobile strategy is non existent other than the Apple partnership. Cloud is struggling - most people don't have a clue on how to compete with AWS or Azure. Management identifies some people as worthy and keeps paying them all the perks. Lately, I have seen a lot of average techies become STSMs.

review_title: Work Experience Highly Dependent On Team & Manager
pros: There are a few managers that are great mentors and want to help with your career growth. The opportunity to work with multi-disciplinary groups leads to a lot of learning. It's pretty nice that the pay is above average and more importantly you have the opportunity to work with people who are equally passionate about healthcare as you are.
cons: In general, the company is not very organized, has a hard time synchronizing among the same groups within offices and among other offices. Depending on location - culture is non- existent. Some groups have no work-life balance, while others do. Some products never see the light of day (lack of funding, lack of organization), it all depends on what team you are on. The quality of managers is a 50/50 toss up, and favoritism among the top managers is apparent. The opportunity to step into leadership is available, but the ability  to continuously grow and learn applicable industry skills in this environment is questionable.

review_title: Not a good place to work
pros: Nothing I can see at this moment and future
cons: Brainless leaders ,worst decision making with out even looking at the outcome.

review_title: Great place to work and advance at some cost. (nothing comes free anyways)
job_title: Software Engineer in San Jose, CA
pros: And endless scope and area to develop a person career. Unlike many competing company where career area available for changes and availability to do so. Many competing company do not have breadth and depth of  areas to work on. For example.. if one wishes to pursue career in an another area, this company is where it will provide ypou options to learn and try different area. It is highly encourage to learn and explore. Where-as the competing companies make it difficult to move from one position to another with same company. IBM is like a min country within. Its upto an employee to make or break..most of the time.
cons: The biggest one being is the salaries, they tend to be at 80% of the market level.. which for some is a significant gap. If IBM were to narrow this gap, then folks may stick around more.. but then there maynot be more position available.  Other downside is, the company being so large, its like an elephant when it comes to responding to market needs/situation.

review_title: Excellent employer that offers employees rich and varied careers
pros: IBM offers good career development guidance and support, allowing employees to move among job roles and make for a very long and challenging career. There is a lot of encouragement among senior leadership to pursue opportunities that allow you to stretch your capabilities and develop new skills. IBM is also incredibly flexible and understanding of employees' needs to balance family and children with careers. Working from home is a great benefit and doesn't take away from opportunities, and isn't a problem considering everyone is connected and able to work remotely given our technology and collaborative tools. Great place to work.
cons: As with any large company, it is incumbent upon employees to establish themselves within their job roles and take responsibility for their own career development and mobility. For an individual who is shy or not comfortable with taking matters into their own hands, this could be perceived as a downside. While I personally do not find this to be a downside, there is also the matter of organizational structure and permissions, which some could call "red tape." Given the task of managing tens of thousands of people, employees do have to adhere to some practices that can be somewhat cumbersome.

review_title: My time here has been full of challenges, adventures and some of the best people to work with and for.
pros: The people at IBM are some of the best in the world. The size of the company means that you can do just about anything you could imagine. If you're looking for a different career path, it could be available by just building the right connections.
cons: The pay structure is generally lower than peer organizations (unless you're an executive). The "pay philosophy" will keep it this way for a long time. The bureaucracy can be maddening at times and the speed of decisions can be glacial, so a healthy sense of humor and a lot of patience is a must. Global roles can amplify this issue through the lens of cultural dynamics.

review_title: Not What It Used To Be
pros:
Depending on your manager and your position, you can work from a home office.  
Obviously IBM has name recognition.
cons:
PBC rating system is seriously flawed.  Even as a 2+ (strong performer) there are no salary increases.  In over 4 years with 2 and 2+ ratings, no salary increase.  
The executive management cares about nothing except lining their pockets before they jump ship with their golden parachutes. 
Despite continued claims by our CEO, there is no true direction for the company, only fluff and vaporware.  
Despite continued losses in revenue and decline in stock price, CEO was awarded a $3.6M bonus while massive layoffs continue. 
No longer any chance of moving to new opportunities within different organizations unless you are a "good ole boy".

pros: Pay was good, better than many other companies in AZ for Admin type of job.  IBM got every cent out of you and more.  Work from home.  No time cards or clocking in.  There is a level of trust in working from home as long as you get the job done.  You learn to be a professional in every sense of the word.  It is sink or swim.
cons: They just pile the work on which got to the point where it was unbearable to manage.  Management could not really do anything about it because they were strapped.  There was no one to help and no hire tickets.  I think eventually all business will be in a different country which is where they are headed for cheaper leases of property and labor.  First line management has no pull.  This used to be a great company to work for...I'd still recommend a couple years for experience then get out.

job_title: Summit Program in San Francisco, CA
pros:
There are some amazing pros to this job. The first is of course the effectiveness of training. Over 6 months, you will visit cities all across the country so that IBM can help to infuse over 100 years of experience into your training. This includes seminars, mock meetings, intensive training, shadowing, testing, mentoring, and much more. This training prepares you well for what you will face in a career at IBM or anywhere else. It provides you with a wide breadth and depth of knowledge over sales, technology, and people skills.
Summits are well respected and looked at as if we hold the future, which we may. We are looked upon with admiration from our leaders, which is an amazing feeling. There is also a very close relationship with your peers. As you train with the same group for 6 months, you become very close. The summit managers are some of the most amazing people that I have had the pleasure of working with.
cons: The traveling can be a lot, and there is a constant fear of not finding a team, or being relocated.

review_title: Great company, if you are in Security, Cognitive and Cloud
job_title: Senior Security Architect in Toronto, ON
pros: One of the most ethical companies I have ever worked for, fair promotion process, friendly environment, and the best work/life balance you you will ever see in the market. Work from home is a viable option, as long you deliver your results. The new IBM is open to innovative ideas, and is growing a lot (investing) in the Security, Cognitive and Cloud spaces. If you are in one of these 3 areas, there is a lot of potential, career development opportunities, and you will be working on the most exciting and biggest projects in the world.
cons: Processes are still a given in IBM, and you either adapt to learn it or you will get buried in approvals and reviews. Also, if you are in other business outside of Cloud, Security or Cognitive, your experience might vary - there are of course good successful projects coming from hardware/systems divisions, but the 3 other areas seem to be getting more of attention, for a good reason. Focus.

review_title: Great place with true academy-like research environment
job_title: Research Staff Member in Yorktown Heights, NY
pros: Flexibility (work from home or from my home country), research environment similar to academia (flexibility and long term goals) , excellent work-life balance, ability to find experts on any field (from math, physics, social science, operating systems, programming, supercomputing, weather, aeronautics, ...) in the very same building!  Just knock on their door and start the brainstorming. Each of us have a private (not shared) office were we can do meeting, discuss, etc. and do whatever we want.
cons: It does not provide the "modern" environment and 'cool' things like free food services, or cooking lessons, etc. as other tech companies... I guess this is mainly because the workforce is older than in other tech companies, so people does not care about these extra 'cool' things... which in the end, the things are 'cool' the first day but then you realize that you just walk to your desk and work most of the days.  I just miss the free food, but with the good salary all these tech companies have, what is the % of savings because free food? <1%?

review_title: Wish I started my career at IBM - Great place to learn and grow
pros: for IBM is not an employer its where my heart and soul are. its a place I look forward each day to interact, collaborate, learn, face new challenges with brilliant IBMers and Win battles for Clients and win their hearts. Each day is a learning because the people are so knowledgeable and helpful. The learning systems are amazing incl Online courses. classroom trainings are superb with hands on. for e.g. there was this course where the instructor practically video graphed and showed areas of improvement in presentations! rather than boring lecture. The projects are cutting edge and challenging. IBM provides me flexibility to incorporate fresh ideas. For smart people IBM provides great career opportunities. There is great recognition for solid performers. I've received good # of promotions in short time and recognized by management. You have great flexibility to change your jobs. Overall, I only wish IBM was my first company I would like to retire with IBM as my employer.
cons: Nothing I know of and think of

pros:
IBM is still IBM.  When one reads about what IBM does for the world, one can't help but take pride working for such a great and innovative company who has survived more than 100 years because it continuously reinvents itself.

The available learning (Your Learning) for all employees, the opportunities given to move from one role to another.

Constant effort to simplify.

Diversity and inclusion are really taken seriously.
cons:
Tendency to get frustrated with leaders as a number of them are pretentious.  They say engagement is important and a priority but it's just lip service.

Different policy, approach, process, culture, even physical set up of offices in each country or organization within the company - it does not feel like it's one IBM company.

pros: Flexible work option (2 days per month). PMP certification reimbursable after approval by management.  It is possible to gain a secret clearance (to move to the DC area).  Descent entry level experience. 401k vested at start and employer match at 6%. Medical and dental benefits. Pretty stable environment.
cons: They say because the cost of living is lower they offer a low wage. Entry level starts between band 1-4 which is around $12.50 and $18.50 per hour. If you want to transfer to another department, be prepared to be low balled through your IBM career.  It is extremely difficult to transfer, get promoted or obtain a substantial pay increase.  Employee portion of medical benefits are expensive! The local area is not good. IBM is operating at model in which they acquire low cost resources and bill the client high; they want they want to invest as little as possible in their employees in low cost areas.  Someone else said they are trying to hire locally because they can't attract or retain good talent outside of this black hole. It is the truth.

review_title: Process driven company with an offshore direction
job_title: Senior Infrastructure Advisory Professional in Calgary, AB
pros: Profitable company which is well organized.  Forward thinking and profit driven
cons:
Very aware of the need to drive costs down and offshore of most technical roles is expected.  This is not speculation but a published plan.  

IBM's benefit plan is the worst I have seen in my 20 year career.  Very flexible with high cost to emplyees with hard to claim processes.  Many if not most opt out.  I have never seen payouts in a year exceeding cost to employee.

I am on working notice right now with a 7 year employee status.
Do not expect a severage package either as that is costs to IBM.  Also do not expect  to be able to fight in court for any severance package above the statuary minimum.  IBM will provide working notice equal to the required mimumum.  t IBM does not provide references for staff, only a record of employment.  This is officiial policy (Managers know this), but is not disclosed to employees.  Beware as it hinders you when looking for work.

You are competing with IBMers in India who work for approx 9,000 a year for your job!

I personally provided training for my position to IBMers from India.   Current policy is that all work must first be 'bid' from low cost center.

review_title: Great company, weak management in the Nordics
job_title: Senior IT Architect in Stockholm, Stockholm
pros:
As a technical professional IBM is a unique place to work and offers outstanding possibilities to work on challenging and ground breaking projects.
Great possibilities for global networking and projects.
Very open, friendly and supportive culture.
High degree of freedom to manage your own work and life.
A genuine industry leader, most of our competitors want to be more like us.
cons:
It is a huge global corporation with the associated processes and politics.
Salaries in Sweden are low compared to competitors (but they offer very generous pension and parental leave benefits)
Ridiculous focus on cost cutting. We all understand why employers need to reduce costs, sometime extensively, but it has now gone so far in IBM Nordics that it is embarrassing.

review_title: Good Learning opportunity...But no other growth...
pros:
Working from Home option
Learn many technologies available in ur team
Brand value
cons:
(1) No Salary hikes at all... You will frustate with salary and leave this organization after long wait... 
     With 0% hike rate..probably you will get same salary slip after 5 years...

(2)  No onsite opportunities. May be 1 in 100 get onsite opportunity. Others will wait forever.

(3)   Always asks to work more so that it can earn more money from Customers... But they never   
      bothers about you.

(4)  It cries to pay bonus amount. Very least in the market... 

(5) If you join as fresher...gone case...you are dead...You won't get any type of growth...

(6) Outside laterals joining will get double salary with your same experience in the company.

pros:
Work from home options.
Good vacation and sick time policies.
Good medical for single employees.
Coworkers are very capable and willing to help.
cons:
Limited growth opportunity.
Inadequate product funding.
Dwindling local workforce..
Lack of innovation opportunity.
Products are in continuing maintenance mode.
IBM prefers to buy companies with new technology rather develop it themselves.
Heavy on process rather than innovation and improvement.
Large families can pay more than $13,000 in premiums for health insurance.
Constant reduction in employee benefits.
Constant downsizing.
Responsibilities pile up due to attrition with no backfill.
Employees are inefficient due to their broad scope of responsibilities.

review_title: Unsatisfactory - Employees Powerless due to HR policies
job_title: Managing Consultant in Midtown Toronto, ON
pros: It will boost your moral, looks good on your resume that you working for Big4, good pay & benefits.
cons:
Corporate politics at its worst, bureaucratic, management in self survival mode, manipulating results by term laying off employees every term to stay float & show profitability to the share holders.

Consulting became - sheer body shopping model, no job security, managers may be busy running for new business neglecting existing client - clients & employees growing dissatisfied.  

Alarm - Big ship heading in the path of Iceberg !!!

Due to Big consulting companies expensive implementation cost, customers exploiting them to analyze their business & provide the best solutions. After stealing their solution, hiring mid sized consulting companies or independent contractors to implement the solution at much cheaper cost. 

Result - Big consulting companies consistently losing business to the mid sized companies & hard working employees are been thrown out mercilessly yet managers saving their own skins.

review_title: Iconic company in a downward spiral driven by short term thinking and overemphasis on cost cutting
pros: Strong brand name, smart coworkers, interesting work, flexible working arrangements (in some roles, primarily internal roles rather than consulting).
cons: The company is under pressure and the response has been excessive focus on cost rather than growing revenue.  This is driven by a need to meet quarterly figures and has jeopardised the long term health of the company.  Years of meeting figures through underinvestment, travel bans, cutting employee compensation (especially through lack of or minuscule bonuses and decreased benefits), cancelling training, moving jobs to India, etc. have put the company in a poor position to compete.  Extreme miserliness has destroyed morale.  This is a company that has removed all office supplies and cut the janitorial staff so much that rat traps are now required to control a vermin problem.  Span of control is so large that career development and coaching is pretty much non existent.

pros: Nice people, decent benefits. Can have long-term benefits if you get the right manager and you constantly remind them of your career goals. Open concept can lead to better collaboration if your team/project works that way.
cons: Typical large enterprise, slow to move or adapt. Lots of promises. Poor equipment for an IT company. People packed in. Depending on client no work from home. Extra hours, work weekends four times a year. Little appreciation for extra effort, you may get something at the end of the year, nothing in between. Poor communication, things tend to come in huge company-wide emails that you don't have time to read. Poor planning, lots of last minute stuff. Cube farm desks so can be loud at times. Lots of new staff/new grads putting pressure on longer-term employees. Office is in the middle of nowhere. You'll like it if the consultant lifestyle is your thing and don't mind a fast growing and young office.

pros: Really great flexibility (home office). Pleasant & nice colleagues on the practitioner level (management is another story - see cons). If you work hard, show initiative and innovation and can be a little political, you can advance in your career.
cons: Salary & benefits are not competitive. Work loads are not balanced across teams (some teams have hardly any work, others are doing - unpaid! - overtime. The performance reviews are often based on the senior managements ideas of you (not your actual work) & the whole review system is taken as a joke by most employees. A lot of employees in the US & Western European countries are rude to the rest of the IBMers. The company's reality recently is cost cutting in every way possible. Most senior managers have zero people or process skills & should never have been given manager positions in the first place.

job_title: Senior Strategy Consultant in Armonk, NY
pros:
1. Good work life balance.
2.  Even though IBM is  considered an old tech company, it is investing a lot of money on new areas.  Even if the new initiatives in AI, Watson, Blockchain do not turn into success stories, you can get hands on experience in them.
cons:
1. Layers on layers of management.  Nightmare for any kind of change management activity.  Leadership understands this, but they tend to respond by adding separate management chains to cut through the original bureaucracy.   And of course, this ends up adding more confusion.  
2. Very margin driven company.  With declining revenues, they continue to focus on cutting more costs, instead of finding ways to maybe invest and grow.  The management layers sit secure, the cost cutting affects the lower level employees.  Promotions get delayed, frequent hiring freezes etc.  New divisions like Watson get investments, the rest of the company is get cut to the bone, resulting in declining employee morale.

review_title: Your life? Oh come on: client first..
pros: There are a lot of good people in this company. You can find friends sometimes and not just colleagues.
cons:
I don't know where to start. Probably I'll start with the work/life balance: it's horrible.
Tenths and tenths of overtime cumulated without compensation; Time off in lieu only goes at the discretion of your line manager or team leader which sometimes doesn't even really know the hard work you've been doing but it's always eager to point out that you don't really work 8 hrs because you take breaks or sometimes you arrive at 9.09 am instead of 9, while nobody ever complained when you stayed in the office untill 9. 10 or even 11 Pm to get the job done at your best. Seriously?
Also career programs are very weak. The ISSC it's one big turtle. You can stay in the same position for years without really getting any significant better salary or quality or responsibility: only more work to do because you're "the expert" now.

job_title: Senior Applications Developer in Cairo, Cairo Governorate
pros:
Working from home policy. 
Working on a lot of projects with different countries.
cons:
Very low benefit package compared to other companies in the market.
Never cares about the employees if they even love what they are doing or not all IBM cares about if you are assigned to project and there is a client paying you.
You have to be utilized and achieve the 5 dimensions of success just to be good employee like you have to work on full time and after doing your full time just continue study and learn and help others to be good employee.
Working with legacy technologies just to run away from supporting customers after delivering the solutions.
Sellers will always ruins your life because they always prefer to sell IBM products which is extremely expensive than competitors so all good projects fly away to another competitor who have reasonable prices.
In case you try to complain about anything you'll receive one answer "This is how IBM works".

review_title: Great If You Can Get In, But No Job Security
job_title: Customer Success Specialist in Portland, OR
pros: As with anyplace, it is the team you end up on that determines the real work environment. Every single individual I worked with was supportive and lovely The benefits are good. Health insurance is not so good unless you get promoted enough to afford the more exoensive offerings.
cons: There is little to no job security, you are pretty much a disposable cog in a giant machine and your redundancy is inevitable. In such a rapidly changing industry, IBM sheds the employees of the companies they merge with every year, as soon as whatever agreement to keep the staff employed for expires. They view people as the most expendable and renewable resource and will throw yu away as soon as your sector starts to hint an losing profit.

review_title: Capitalist infringing on innovators by diluting reward and recognition by not sharing the profits with employees.
pros: The teams consisted of seasoned experienced professionals that understood their business and understood how they could apply their own individual skills to the cooperative successful achievements in realizing their objectives with high levels of customer satisfaction based on quality and business transformation value to the clients.
cons: The outsourcing of skilled jobs to low labor global regions has impacted and reduced customer satisfaction and demoralized the skilled base of talent, especially with the repetitive cost reductions cycles involving the resource actions of several thousand unconfirmed "senior" employees that have been laid off when the company balance sheets have been extremely strong cash positive.

review_title: High waste, low salaries, very "old school" management systems.
job_title: Advanced Teleservices Agent in Boulder, CO
pros: It's easy to shine among all the dullards, they have tons of free education available, and the work load is usually pretty light (they over-employ).
cons: Promotions are "open season", so even if you've been on your team for several years, there's a very strong chance someone from another team is going to steal your promotion (even with lateral moves). They outsource their interviews to other managers constantly, meaning that "surprise surprise", that manager's subordinates get the promotions. They hire almost everyone as a "long term supplemental" meaning that your contract ends after a few years no matter how well or poorly you performed during that time, and getting converted to a regular is an act akin to resurrecting the dead.

review_title: Interesting and challenging work, but definitely a company in the midst of a transition.
job_title: Software Engineer in San Jose, CA
pros:
Incredible amount of resources to access, whether it be mentorship or a masters degree, IBM has got your back. This company is focused on building your skills, so it is a great launching pad for people early in their career and lacking experience.

For people are skilled enough in what they do to work from home, IBM is a dream come true.
cons:
IBM doesn't perform cost of living adjustments, in comparison to other Bay Area competition the pay dismal, however if you move out of the Bay Area to say... Texas, where the taxes are low and the living is cheap; you will be making more money than the local competitors.

Aside from compensation: The company spirit is nowhere near the "Silicon Valley energy" I've seen in other tech firms.

pros:
1) My good ideas were paid attention to from the very beginning of my time at IBM. The good ones got implemented and continued to be supported for >10 years so far.
2) I get to work with people from all over the world.
3) I got my Master's education paid for by IBM. I went part-time while working full-time.
4) I got to go on a six-month assignment to India from the U.S. My wife accompanied me.
5) IBM has a great legacy of inclusion, especially for lesbian, gay, bisexual and trans people, as well as for heterosexual women and people with disabilities of all sexual orientations and gender identities.
cons: There is not as much room for advancement into senior roles, depending on the area of the company where you work, i.e., people in sr. leadership positions stay a long time and so there's less room for advancement, but I doubt that's unique to IBM.

review_title: Only for Lazy People who don't want to grow faster (I worked in ISL and left with in 6 months)
pros:
1. Work from home which actually means no work at all as People take work from home option on vacations without doing any work.

2. Come and go anytime you want.

3. So, If you are married and just want to get decent amount of salary without much headache of Work and releases, then IBM is best for you.
cons:
1. You will get relaxed here and won't be able to adjust in other companies in future as you will loose the capability of doing hard work.

2. Nothing is free except Water.. Not even Tea and coffee. It somehow affects me though it is not that costly.

3. And I believe that work 3-4 people do here can easily be done by 1 hard working person with obviously more salary.

4. Salary is less even in ISL (System Labs) and leave GBS which has even more lower.
Real case: People with 5-7 yrs experience in IBM earn less than what others earn (me) with 3 yrs experience get at other good organizations.

review_title: A once great company... destroyed by non-techie managers at all levels
pros:
Flexibility and working from home
Great systems and tech available
cons:
Some divisions within IBM like ex-Lotus are plagued by old boys networks, largely incompetent managers who feel like little tyrants and love to dominate their little kingdoms, nepotism. If you are unfortunate enough to be stuck in said division then the future is rather bleak. Applying for internal jobs is usually unsuccessful due to prejudice towards certain job families or simply because your current manager decides to throw a spanner in the works. 
Having a solid tech/engineering background usually hinders any career advancements whereas management loves bs artists and yes men who are not a threat to them. 
Nice honest people generally are driven away or into submission whereas aggressive offensive employees are actually rewarded... to keep them quiet and progress the status quo.

review_title: IBM is great. Baton Rouge IBM is awful
job_title: Applications Developer in Baton Rouge, LA
pros:
Core IBM is a great company. As a whole, IBMers are probably the nicest group of people I have ever worked with.  Everyone in Core IBM has a lot of integrity and excellent work ethic.
Health care benefits are very good.
Baton Rouge IBM is a great place to start, if you're fresh out of college.  Major resume boost, and you really do learn a lot on projects.
cons:
The Baton Rouge CIC is quite possibly the worst part of IBM.  Most managers are unable or unwillingly to do their jobs.
The pay is shockingly low, and "promotions" are insultingly small. I received a "promotion" and it was only a $3000/yr increase...
I spend a lot of weekends working, and I usually don't get home until 9pm. I calculated my hourly rate: it's $14/hr.  Before taxes.
Baton Rouge CIC is a great place to start but not a place to stay.  Get in, get your experience, get out.

review_title: Nice place, nice people, good culture but everything is very slow
pros: Working time is very flexible, is half of the cases home office is permitted. Everything is process oriented that is as a pro as a con. But I prefer to have processes. Very large knowledge based, huge education center with tons of online education materials. Lots of tools are available for use (conference calls, e-meetings, ticketing systems, etc.). You will also work with people from different countries in different time zones. You can find several great initiative here where you can think and collaborate with other. Offices are nice and friendly, the company has a nice and friendly atmosphere.
cons: The organization is huge, everything goes very slowly, you have to wait days of weeks to get your email answered. It is hard to find with whom you have to work with, you have to engage colleagues from other departments via ticketing systems. the company is currently reinventing itself that is also a very slow and frustrating procedure.

job_title: Services Client Representative in Smyrna, GA
pros: The people are wonderful, bright and professional.  First Line Managers in my experience are superb.
cons: Quarterly layoffs since IBM hasn't hit Wall Street earnings for 22 straight quarters.  There is no job security here.  Quotas have been set so high the sales force isn't earning any commissions in comparison to past years; this is a way of cost savings.  IBM is a depressing place to work when you know regardless of your effort they will blow you out eventually.  IBM no longer hires seasoned professionals - they only hire young people under 30, again as a way of cost savings via salary.  In GTS if you close a deal it has to go to a War Room internally to see if they have the internal resources to execute.  Nobody is happy here.  Ginni the CEO is the worst and high level management simply doesn't care - they just protect their piece of the pie while the ongoing layoffs continue.

review_title: Nice place to be, reasonable place to work
pros:
A lot of opportunities to move and get experience
Multicultural environment
Reasonable offices
Nice people
cons:
Salaries not re-negotiable even if making big position jumps or you prove being a very good asset for the company
Salary increases have a maximum percentage per year
Salaries for already existent employees can not adapted according to local market growth (huge growth)... you're obliged to leave the company
The company is interested in selling, selling, selling... the support after is not so important neither what the customer needs
Stupid technical decisions are made by people with no skills or knowledge, which do not consult the specialists 
Lives in it's own "bubble" from technology perspective, being years behind a lot of other companies
Quantity and "green" matters, quality or flexibility not so much
Many small reoccurring administrative tasks, which can be easily fully automated, but they are not... this is eating people patience  and time, highly increasing the feel of "I need to do something"
Great ideas, disaster implementations because of not consulting the specialists

review_title: Has it's good points but no longer the company or employer it used to be
job_title: Senior Marketing Manager in Basingstoke, England
pros: Very progressive in terms of flexible working options including working from home. Large number of business areas provide, at least in theory, a wide variety of career development options without changing employer.  IBM is a recognised company name throughout the industry which can help in your professional work (in terms of opening doors, getting appointments etc) and also is a name people of heard of outside the industry.
cons: IBM no longer seems to treat its people well, at least in the UK.  Employee benefits have been incrementally reduced with every turn and annual 'update', leading to a very cynical workforce (in terms of 'the company' and its anticipated next steps) which does nothing for morale or productivity. Many long-serving IBM employees continue to be motivated by their pride in doing a good job (for the company, their colleagues, themselves) and wanting to support their colleagues, however overall satisfaction with IBM management is undoubtedly at an all time low.

review_title: Good employees laboring under difficult circumstances.
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Lexington, MA
pros: The pay's good for senior talent.  The benefits are decent.
cons: Bloated bureaucracy and overbearing processes.  Much lip-service paid to Open Source, but legal approval processes to be able to use it make it agonizing and slow to actually get permission to use it.  Patronizing and often downright mean management.  Management which often explicitly stifles and punishes any hints of dissent; aka, "honest opinions".  Much arrogance about being "cutting edge", whereas the reality is that IBM is too slow to adopt new technologies.  Co-option of terms like "agile", applying them to whatever IBM currently does rather than actually changing and "walking the walk".  Constant fear of being on the "wrong" project or working for the "wrong" manager, which may lead you vulnerable to the next round of layoffs.  A performance review process which often bears little relationship to reality, with only managers and a few "architects" giving any input into your review, as opposed to your actual peers with whom you work.  Lack of money to buy equipment, resulting in obsolete computers on desktops, and a constant struggle to find adequate hardware to test on.

review_title: IBM HAS LOST RESPECT FOR THE INDIVIDUAL.  FIND A BETTER COMPANY TO WORK FOR!
pros: Good benefits, good people, much autonomy in professional positions
cons: IBM has very limited upward pay opportunities in many positions.  You may start with a competitive salary but it is hard to increase it.  IBM then lays off senior workers or forces them into retirement.  The top performers have very little work/life balance.  Work/life balance is a joke.  Relative contribution is used as a semantic tool to give average ratings which in turn save the company money.  The ratings are skewed for only a few high performers to get exceeded or outstanding ratings leading to higher salaries. Don't believe that IBM has true respect for the individual.  They don't!

job_title: Project Leader in San Jose, CA
pros: Still some good people left, and good technology. I worked for IBM for many years, and they gave me a lot of good opportunities. The technical vitality is/was unmatched - there are some really amazing tools and applications developed by people pretty much in their spare time which could easily spawn off a startup. Yet the employees just do it for free. And management hasn't figured out how to put a dollar value on that.
cons: too much management, too few people left who actually do stuff. Morale is very low after many rounds of layoffs, and incompetent management. I in the past few years, things declined rapidly. Our group was clearly not valued by management, even though the technical field, our partners and customers absolutely loved us. So we suffered the death of a thousand cuts till I finally couldn't take it and left. I realized you don't have to work with depressed, demoralized people.

review_title: Better than no job at all
job_title: Senior Security Analyst in Boulder, CO
pros: All of the best reasons to work at IBM went out the window in the late 1990's. They started dropping salaries, training and educational benefits even then, before 9/11/2001.
cons:
In it's heyday, IBM set the standard for how employers should treat their employees. They were the 'gold standard' to which all others looked as an example. Outsourcing, corporate greed, and a host of other factors have eroded IBM as a place to work to the point where every IBMer I know is disillusioned. 

I have seen new hires come in with high ideals only to have their enthusiasm crushed after a few years. It did not used to be that way. Hard working people put in 60 hour weeks with no recognition, and very small raises, if any.

review_title: Great work life balance, opportunity to work with a range of companies
job_title: Managing Consultant in New York, NY
pros: As a consultant, overall view of company is largely, if not wholly dependent on the client engagement that consultant is staffed on and practice area. I have had a mix of successful, balanced projects as well as challenging. There is a lot of autonomy and career direction is largely up to the employee to take the initiative and get the proper face time, otherwise you can be invisible since you rarely work with your career manager on engagements. Every few months there are check-ins that allow you to decide if you want to continue in the role you are in or change directions. That is valuable. There are also work remote project opportunities so you don't get burnt out on travel
cons: If you are on a project that is not in your practice area- which happens to avoid the bench, it is easy to become invisible. With 400,000 employees, it is up to you to ask for what you want and ask the tough questions. Also, recently, consultants in commerce and Sterling have been having a hard time getting staffed since companies are slow to sign or process is dragged out. Take note.

review_title: Great company but very process have, has some drones.
pros: This is one of the largest technology companies in the world. If you put your mind to it, you can easily advance anywhere and fit a vast number of positions. The company has many resources and seems to pay well. Many very intelligent people (tech side at least), and you have a wealth of knowledge and potential at your hands. Not to mentioned the message this company's name sends on a resume for then future.
cons: Some employees, especially sales orientied are very process heavy, seem like drones, mindlessly following the norm. As an Engineer, my work with other technical side people has been great, but the sales side seems solely interest in closing, making money, and moving on to the next. (I know this is what sales is, but some I've noticed will throw their own co-workers under the bus whenever convenient.

review_title: A wonderful company hamstrung by layers of clueless, bumbling middle management.
job_title: Cyber Security Engineer in New York, NY
pros:
Good, but not great, salary.
Above average job security.
Many job opportunities.
Generally good, if somewhat thread-worn, working conditions, and work from home opportunities.
Company is starting to understand that moving work to China and India is a disaster.
Flexibility in work hours and time off
cons:
Company is not committed to employee training; no rotations, online training is just window dressing.
Bad management, especially unnecessary layer upon layer of ignorant middle management, permeates much of the business.
Constant, slow decline in employee benefits.
Only a 401K retirement plan.  Company match is not credited to employee until December.
Management's constant nit picking, over-reporting to each other, and distraction from job assignments.
The PBC annual evaluation is ineffective window dressing; it is simply a compensation management tool.
Silly budget constraints on travel: forced to fly at inconvenient times,  stay in sub-par hotels, and rent undersize cars.
Constraints on conference attendance impede ability to stay current and maintain network.

review_title: A Culture of Fear and Distrust..."Choke the Wild Duck"
job_title: Senior Systems Engineer in Seattle, WA
pros: As an external Executive  hire I was paid (Market Rates) which was 40% more than the veteran IBMers that were there for 20-30 years. I made more than my FLM which was a big surprise to me.
cons: IBM claims that they want to make significant changes to the way they are doing business and say we need to  "Treasure the Wild Duck" but in fact they "Choke the Wild Duck" and put them at the top of the lay off list. Ideas and Opinions are not welcome and in fact there is a huge culture of lies, distrust, back stabbing, dishonesty, and fear across the whole of IBM. The PBC process has made it easy for the VPs to get rid of any and everyone that does not march to the beat of their drum. As a result, it is not a place for creativity, new ideas, loyal employees, collaboration, or a sense of well being. Many people are suffering from Post Traumatic Stress due to the horrible work environment and I know that some have even have heart attacks due to the stress.

review_title: still a great company (beside GSDC departments)
pros: In IBM you can learn some rare technologies, which are not popular but if you will get an offer, it is usually well paid. A lot of interesting projects are also an advantage, nevertheless in such a big comapny approval processes ruin the lifecycle of projects.
cons: I worked in GSDC, poorly managed, but still I think IBM is a great company with a lot of opportunities, especially when you want to work with mainframes, AIX systems, power systems - it's the only place to get some knowledge about them. Beside that, I think management decisions, which affects "normal" employees are truly unfair. They don't care about you, your development needs and do not award you if you are trying to do the best. Thus, I decided to quit and I don't regret. There are still companies which cares about their workers. It's a shame that in GSDC you don't even have a monitor to work, you have to buy one by your own...

review_title: MARCH 2 mass layoff - Don't work @ IBM - here's why
pros: Working with smart & dedicated people who are not executives; colleagues who feel they are making a positive impact on society.
cons:
On March 2 2016 IBM gave the pink slip to thousands (IBM won't disclose how many). I was a senior employee with very good annual reviews and spent 13 years of my career contributing to IBM. The company changed its severance pay structure in 2016. When severance pay was 6 months, that was a big deal. But now that severance pay is only 1 month - regardless of years of service ! The greed and arrogance of the IBM execs to change this policy in anticipation of the mass layoffs announced on March 2 2016 is vulgar and sickening.

Greed of executives at expense of those employees who have put in years of service.

IBM preaches that IBM takes care of it's own - that's a lie !

pros:
THIS IS FOR THE CLEVELAND IBM EXPLORYS LOCATION ONLY: BEWARE!!!!

It doesn't matter because the Cons are so horrible. I wish I could have stayed because I am fascinated with what the next level of cognitive computing will be in healthcare. But this place is toxic.
cons:
I was hired to help with a newly formed services team. Within 2 days, I realized that the harassing and intimidating work environment by a senior manager was not only IGNORED by senior leadership but by the onsite HR representative, and it is creating an unsustainable working situation where everyone is in fear of this person and their job. 

I do not know why IBM is allowing this, but great people are running for the doors. They had an employee survey which identified this person's behavior and how it's affecting the staff, and the SLT chose to ignore it. After the employees put themselves on the line by speaking up, they no longer trust anyone and feel that their voices were ignored. WORST JOB I have ever had.

pros:
If you are willing to be a team player and work hard - you will be rewarded and motivated by management. 
Again , if you work hard, show you care, do a good job, then your management will support you. 
My last 4 managers have been Italian. Once they see a committed Rep, they will look after you throughout your career in IBM, encourage/help you get new roles within IBM and learn new parts of the business, which is a great way to develop. I have learnt a lot through the amazing managers I have worked with.
cons:
Negative colleagues that complain about everything, don't recognize their own negative status and comedown, which is quite sad. Complain about management because they can't become a manager, complain about their job etc.. I try to stay away from that type of colleague.
Other cons would be cheaper food in canteen. 
More social activities.

job_title: Senior Vice President, Transformation and Operations in Armonk, NY
pros:
•	IBMers: working with incredibly talented people from all around the world.
•	IBM's Values.
•	Work-life balance - flexibility. 
•	Great place to learn and grow – skills, experiences, build relationships.
•	You are a part of something meaningful; being in service of human potential and progress (in tech, business and society).
cons:
Cons:
•	IBM has been built on foundational principle of continuous reinvention, if you are uncomfortable with change, it is probably not be the right place for you. 
•	In a company as big as IBM, if you don't invest time in building your own skills and capabilities you may fall behind or get stuck.

review_title: If you're lucky you'll be in a good place
pros:
Talents are respected and rewarded in IBM. Honestly speaking I get way higher salary than my friends who joined in other service based companies in a span of 3 years.
Very professional treatment from leads, manager etc. But I've heard politics are there in other projects but I've never experienced.
cons:
Most of the projects are support project in GBS. So freshers should think twice if they have different offers. Only lucky one's will good techs since technology assignment random. At least it's what told.
Salary of Fresher's has been revised in recent years. But the salary of experienced person is not revised(Not talking about the yearly and promotion hikes).
It's very difficult to move to a different technology in a different project.
It's very difficult for People with poor rating and reputation in the account to get hike and promotion. Especially the yearly hike is not in those cases. In IT it's terrible because till the next hike you'll be getting the same salary for years.

pros: systems, policies, office decor, location
cons: employees not treated well..lack of work life balance

review_title: Great respect as an IBM employee in the eyes of others.  And that's where it all ends....
pros:
- Great to have on your resume
- Work from home option
- Treated as an adult (without managers looking over your shoulder)
- Benefits are above average
cons:
- Jobs are outsourced, and outsourced employees are not held accountable
- Too much red tape which does not allow for any innovation
- Putting in extra hours is expected of each employee as departments are always understaffed and employees are expected to pick up the work load
- Almost impossible to get things done as everyone hides behind policies!
- Perks do not really exists unless your in sales, promises of salary alignments to market value etc never usual show up.
- Work life balance, that term doesn't exist

pros:
- Challenging projects with unique opportunities for employees to develop their skills 
- Smart, friendly, and knowledgeable colleagues 
- Excellent benefits (Dental/Health/Vision insurance, awesome 401(k) , discounts on many 3rd party products and services and many more) 
- Excellent work/life balance (very flexible work environment; probably, this is the biggest + )
- Massive technical resources for employees to grow their skills (eg. online technical library (Books 24x7), workshops, classes, etc)
- Tons of different projects and it is usually fairly easy to switch between projects, so you won't get bored
cons:
- Low base pay
- Promotions are extremely slow or non-existence 
- Performance reviews are ridiculous and your work will be compared with the rest of the people in your level (no matter how hard you work on a project, you could still get a low rank and no raise)
- Too much bureaucracy 
- If you are thinking about getting your master/PhD, Tuition Reimbursement is like lottery, you sign up and pray to get it
- Absolutely no innovation; if the current solution works, DO NOT TOUCH IT kind of mindset. Hence, the management is very resistance to new ideas.

review_title: Patent "center of excellence" is a JOKE!
pros:
Relaxed, laid back atmosphere to work
Plenty of walking around and chatting
Opportunity to learn IF you have the right team leader and cultivate a friendship with the top manager
cons:
Focus entirely on Quantity, not Quality or Complexity of work submitted
Nepotism runs rampant
No incentive to do good work, just churn it out to be rewarded
No opportunity for advancement - nobody wants to help you move up since that would leave them with finding a replacement and Rochester is not a great attraction
Pay is roughly 40% below of market rates - just for those with a BS degree, around 50-60% below market if you have a JD or USPTO registration;
I left and was offered 2x my last salary when I inquired about returning.

pros:
Career paths in the professions such as PM, Architect, Consultant or Technical Specialists are well defined and promotion is possible via internal certification and job performance.
If you're in the right job you have flexiblity about where you work eg from home.  But it depends on the line manager.  Some are old school.  Don't assume you'll be able to work from home.
The more senior you are the more autonomy you have.
cons: Management are always looking for ways to save a tiny bit of cash by reducing staff benefits.  There are fewer desks than employees and hot desking is often forced even if the work requires office attendance everyday.  No Internet expenses, even if you work from home because of the lack of desks.   No rubbish bins at desks in order to save cleaner cost.  You must find the single rubbish bin on each floor everytime you have a bit of rubbish otherwise it accumulates on your desk.   Tea and coffee in the kitchen has gone.  Somehow it is thought that staff heading out for coffee will somehow save money and improve productivity.

job_title: Global Eccosystem Manager in New York, NY
pros: Had an awesome 20+ year career with about 8 different jobs that let me grow in many different directions. I always had a focus on strategic partnerships because as big as IBM is, it can't do everything on its own and its ecosystem is an economy unto itself! I loved working with other IBMers and business partners and was able to have tremendous creative expression that led to business results I am proud of to this day! Great place to grow and develop.
cons: From 2010 to 2015, Ginny the CEO inherited an aggressive profit target that was unachievable as the company did not realize Revenue growth. It took a bit long for the leadership team to realize it and adjust, but hopefuly they will realize growth again soon. The focus on Acquisitions is necessary but Mergers should be considered as well to move the top line more aggressively.

pros:
- There are top-notch people that you run into
- Work-from-home is still very good, at least in my country
- Relaxed atmosphere at my levels
- Good community of overseas employees, which enables work to be performed after-hours.
cons:

- Mismatch between what management says and then what they do
- I've watched people hand train their replacements.
