review_title: IBM is old and it shows
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Westford, MA
pros: IBM has some very bright people and some good technology. They allow flexible work hours and location. Benefits and compensation are industry average. Work/life balance is generally pretty good.
cons:
IBM is old and it shows. It doesn't really feel like a technology company. Processes are cumbersome. You can just imagine some ancient mainframe software running the place. 

I worked in the software business group. The overall feeling was that software engineers were interchangeable. There must be something wrong with you if you wanted to be an individual contributor and liked to write code. Promotions and awards were much more about politics than technical merit.

There are too many rules and managers are afraid to push back. Employees are constantly told what they cannot do along and threatened with potential penalties. A couple of examples: print jobs needed to be picked up within 30 minutes or you're cited by security. Office doors need to be locked and blinds drawn when away from your desk for more than 15 minutes. Silly stuff.

review_title: Glad to say I am no longer IBMer
pros:
I was a developer at IBM in Tivoli for a little over two years and started fresh out of school.  Generally, starting salaries (fresh out of college) are fairly competitive. Mostly all of my co-workers were very professional and cordial. Given the size of the company you have an opportunity to move around if you really network well; however, this is getting harder and harder to pull off. Also if you want to work from home there are plenty of opportunities in development, test, project management, IT, etc. that will allow you to do it either full or part-time. Also flex-time was truly flexible; many a time I ran long mid-day errands without anyone raising an eyebrow (rating system is "results" oriented, I'll get to this later). There are some really interesting projects mainly in the Software Group Strategy, Rational, and Lotus pillars if you are good enough to maneuver yourself onto one of those teams.

Health Benefits were quite basic for a big company.  You get a standard 80/20 with about a $700 deductible for free and you payed about $75 a month for each additional dependant.  They had other options that weren't bad but they got expensive quick; however, after the sixth child it's free!  You also can get a lot of discounts such as 25% off cell phone service and employee pricing on GM cars. Vacation was 3 weeks plus 4 - 5 floating holidays per year which effectively meant you got 4 weeks of vacation not including U.S. national holidays out of the gate which is pretty good.  Also the 401(k) match was not to shabby at 6% dollar for dollar.
cons:
Some people joke about executives only caring about the stock price and running their company only worrying about the quarter to quarter results, IBM does it.  This quarter to quarter madness is quite understandable when you realize that a good chunk of the VP's incentives are in stock options.  Why should they care about anything else, but the stock price?  This is where they get brilliant ideas such as taking out loans to buy back company stock instead of using it to build products or buy more companies to gain market share.

And this brings me to my next point.  IBM is not doing very much home growing of products anymore. They tend to buy a company, add some features to the product, slowly let attrition and layoffs take its toll on the U.S. workforce while pushing the product to maintenance mode over in India, China, Argentina, or one of the other BRIC type countries. One of the products I worked on lost about half of its U.S. workforce in two years. Every time someone would leave the company or move to another product team they would not backfill them. If the natural attrition didn't work they would do a layoff and hire replacements in one of the forementioned countries.  The problem with this strategy is the replacements were typically very green and knew their jobs were safe no matter what, making motivation an issue. This combined with constant benefit cuts like Tivoli free sodas/coffee being taken away (oh sorry, the email said they were aligning the drink policy with IBM guidelines) leaves the morale of the U.S. employees effectively in the toilet.  One more note on the drink thing, the email they sent saying they were cutting the free drinks was dressed with the typical corporate language so they had to send up a follow-up email to clarify it. This leads me to my next point.

If you want to be treated like a five year old, work here. There is nothing like working hard through a product release while the executives push/prod, make you work the weekends to keep on schedule and at the end they send one of those "YOU GUYS ROCK" emails which is supposed to motivate us even more. I remember sitting on meetings with fellow employees struggling for recognition with from the executives, it reminded me of dogs fighting for scraps from the table. The scraps being that when review time came around only one or two people would get the highest rating while the other 90% got the solid performer/average rating.  And even if you did get a high rating expect maybe a 5% raise and a 7% bonus woohooo! don't spend it all one place.  For the rest, better luck next year.  Another problem with the rating system was how managers were the only ones with any input and they normally new the least about who was the best and did the most work. Their ignorance not being of their own fault so much as the fault of the countless meetings they were constantly stuck in all day.

Oh yeah, IBMers love meetings, almost always to the detriment of productivity.  The meetings were where all the power grabbing was so usually the loudest voices were listened too and respected. Meaning that if you wanted that high rating you would need to make sure your opinion heard, whether or not it was valid, so as to make sure you could check off that teaming section in your end of the year review.

Now  to get back to my title, this place is not the worst place on earth to work, but it far from the best.  Don't let the fancy "I'm an IBMer" commercials fool you into thinking it is as hip and progressive as Google or Apple.  If you are a go-getter self-starter type you would probably do better working at a start-up or a small company where you can really have an impact.  I remember reading in college about all these famous inventions by IBM and its alumni and startups such as Craigslist started by former IBMers, and for some reason I missed the former part. Yeah, IBM gets a lot of great people, but many of the truly successful ones in the industry are the ones that leave.  If not you could end up like some of my former co-workers in their late 20's early 30's who talk about big dreams outside of the company but get comfortable and never go anywhere. Getting comfortable at IBM is easy to do, but that is the biggest mistake you can make there. With the constant layoffs, make sure to keep an exit plan open so when you leave it is for the betterment of your career, like my case, rather than your group missed its quarterly number by a quarter percent and you get hit by the next "resource action" or "restructuring" (a.k.a. layoff).

So bottom line: feel free to by stock in IBM, just don't work there.

review_title: As good as you choose to make it
pros: IBM has incredibly talented people in just about every area you can imagine.  With networking and career management, you can construct a very interesting and fulfilling career path.  IBM is the type of company where you have to make your own career and define your job role.  Many people who do not enjoy working for IBM are waiting for IBM to take the lead in managing their career.  That will not happen and you risk being treated as an expendable resource.  If you take responsibility for defining your role, there are tremendous opportunities.
cons: Like any large company, there is bureaucracy.  In troubled times, accountants have a tendency to take over and some questionable decisions are made.  This typically passes and a more constructive approach to operating a business returns.

review_title: IBM is not what it used to be, expect little and you will survive.
pros:
Flex - Time - You don't have to kill yourself to get to work before 8AM.
Vacation - For the most part you can take vacations without to much hassle from management.
Stock Purchase Program
Normally your peers are professional so for the most part a pleasant place to work

Salaries: Normally based on a national level not regional - all that has changed. So if you move from Atlanta to NY don't expect a pay raise to cover the additional cost of living. Not very competitive anymore unless you get into higher mgmt levels.

IBM running on bare bones for the last 2 years trying to keep cost down and appease stockholders - little movement, so if you are looking to get ahead- this is not the place for you.

review_title: IBM is a revenue orientated organisation interested in growing its business any cost and does not values it's employees.

- Large organisation who tolerates low achievers by shifting then from one business unit to another i.e. managers do not have the ability to affectively manage their staff.

Instead of inventing the future, they seem to want to copy other people's innovative business ideas, all the while filing new patent after patent on stuff they never product-ize.      {NB. The token gestures of doing the right things by women and minority races are all North American centered.  European women or minority races professionals, rarely progress through the ranks however talented}

review_title: A great company facing a long road back
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Ginni Rometty, IBM's current CEO is focusing on the right things and driving much needed change.  Her focus,  "being essential to our clients", is precisely on target.   IBM employs many of the best and brightest scientists, executives, engineers, developers, technologists,  sales people and managers in the industry.  IBM has stayed current with the work force needs, offering excellent benefits and a challenging work environment with excellent opportunities for advancement and broad experience.
cons: Overly matrixed and overlapping management structures shield mediocre contributors from accountability and frequently allow those who are productive to be lost in "blind" resource actions.   Unreasonable expectations and insufficient support structures impede the efforts for those who want to contribute, want to be accountable, and want to be proud of the organization they represent.

pros: Plenty of self-learning opportunities with access to cutting edge technologies.   Technical leadership team like the fellows and distinguished engineers are helpful and willing to mentor and help with career development for the developers.  Good place for junior developers to start off their career if you are with the right team.
cons: Many of the VPs running the business have been at IBM for too long. Cannot provide product vision or leadership.  Can only focus on making numbers.   Lack of understanding for the product management function (is it a mini GM, outbound marketing or product designer roles?).   No product managers can be good at all functions.   Lack of access to new tools.  IBM's internal built products like Rational are not suited for agile development.

pros:
IBM gives you numerous opportunity to show case your talent. Not just in the field of your Area of work but any additional talent you have. Like singing, Dancing etc.
In IBM India, we got frequent Dance or Zumba workshops along with Painting, Guitar classes and many others.
I am working in IBM as a SAP Security Consultant, so we got a tie up with SAP wherein we got access to their online Library where we can refer all their study material.
If you work hard, you will get the perks. We have many awards like Orion or Spark which is a cash awards for the talented and hardworking employees.
Now the most amazing part and I will cherish this for the rest of my life. The IBM Corporate Services Corps Program.
Every year IBM Sends its top-rated employee for a Pro bono consulting program to any of the developing Countries. Here you get a chance to work with a team of 10 to 15 IBMer’s from 9 or 10 different countries. It’s a non-Profit assignment where you get a chance to serve the Community.
cons: Yearly Increment can be a bit higher.

review_title: It's all about your management team
pros: Vast world wide network of brilliant colleagues.  Most of the people are super helpful and are there to make a difference.  The compensation is competitive and there's a wide variety of assignments you can explore over the course of your career.  There are still some great managers at the company.
cons: The executive management style is increasingly coercive and toxic.   Flawed architectural assumptions and unrealistic business case expectations, by narcissistic senior executives, drives insane employee workloads, and contributes to a depressing high stress work environment.  There is a growing tendency towards micromanagement.  Too many budgetary allocation decisions are made by financial people instead of those responsible to get things done.

review_title: It is complicated for technical people
pros:
Company's reviews mostly depend on policies whether it makes any sense to the reviewer ( Policy is customizable by the project manager, so it varies from project to project )

1. WFH
2. Flexibility
3. Great policies
4. Onsite
5. Relatively less pressure if someone is in technical developer roles and is technically strong - as the teams are big, so work gets distributed, it is upto this employee whether he/she wants to complete others' jobs too without any professional gain.
cons: All the pros are customized by the project and people manager, so varies from project to project and manager to manager. Good work bad work never matters. Only thing matters the most is relationship with the managers. Someone with good reputation with management gets all the benefits and onsite, and the rest gets offshore work, lower ratings and below respectable salaries. Well, the world moves in this way only in the service industry!

review_title: Global company with lots of opportunities.
pros:
- IBM allows flexible working hours which is far more interesting compared to a steady 9 to 5 working schedule.
- It is a global company which means opportunities can present itself anywhere in the world.
- People in IBM, management or non-management are generally laid-back and helpful.
- The pay and benefits in IBM are quite competitive.
- The wide range of business units means you have the opportunities to explore different job fields and industries.
cons:
- Large companies means slower and sometimes lack of communication. 
- Due to the matrix structure, an employee may have several managers to report to, which means it's hard to build a close relationship with your manager(s), especially when many of them work remotely.
- Although there are many opportunities, it may take you a long time to get to the position you want due to standards and structures that must be followed in order to get promoted.

job_title: Advisory Software Engineer in Cary, NC
pros: Stability. The main reason to work for IBM is stability. IBM is less likely to be affected as much as other companies to swings in the job market.
cons: You do not join IBM Software Group because you are a risk taker. This is a place for the risk adverse and it shows within the company. Many within IBM plateau. They do enough to take a paycheck but nothing more. They are not fired up to make the company grow and succeed. It is a place to hide but still take home a decent paycheck.

review_title: Its not the same IBM anymore.
job_title: Senior IT Specialist in Gaithersburg, MD
pros: In my position as a Senior IT Specialist, I have the ability to work from home full time and create my own flexible work schedule.  As long as I get the work done, my immediate management isn't concerned about micro-managing my workload.  While IBM has always provided good benefits, they have dimminished over the years.  For example, the previously guaranteed pension plan is now merged into the 401K plan.
cons: Stupid upper management decisions.  Recently, many IT Specailists were given a 15% pay cut and then required to work overtime to make it up.  I initially did not have any issues with this as I already worked more than enough overtime to make up the 15%.  But, come time for the annual raises, I was not given one despite being rated a top contributor for the last 5 years (very, very rare!).  IBM has taken away the incentive to work hard.

review_title: IBM offers opportunities to those who want it
job_title: Business Development Executive in Austin, TX
pros: The choice to work from home or the office offers a great amount of flexibility especially for women and men.  Respect for work life balance issues is prevalent in most organizations.  IBM is such a large organization that there is a tremendous amount of job opportunities to branch out.  Throughout my 20 years at IBM, I have held positions in Manufacturing, Development Engineering, Marketing and Sales, with the ability to parlay job history and skills aquired into the next job.  The colleagues I work with are competent and the management team I work for is respectful and appreciative of the effort that I put in for IBM.
cons: IBM is a highly matrixed environment, at times, it is confusing who has the lead.  It is a large organization and there is competition within product lines and services groups.  Without strong leadership looing t the bigger picture, it can get very disheartening to work at IBM.  In addition, because it is so large, it frequently takes time to find the right person or right organization to address a question/problem.

review_title: IBM Canada--Great Quality of Life, Oppressive Management Structure
job_title: Sales Support Specialist in Toronto, ON
pros: The best reasons to work for IBM Canada especially early in your career is that it is a great way to learn a lot about many different things.  Of course this is true of any system integrator/management consultancy where you have the opportunity to work on multiple projects for different clients.  IBM is a world leader in many areas and of course there are some extremely talented people.
cons: IBM is not an environment for talented people who think outside-of-the-box and focus on company success above matrix politics.  There are a lot of line managers who are so enmeshed in IBM politics and group think that they have completely lost sight of the company mission.  Risk taking of virtually any kind is universally frowned upon.  This is a very top heavy, bureaucratic institution and a lot of well connected and extraordinarily incompetent people rise while talented visionaries walk.

review_title: The New IBM : Micro-managing the numbers
pros: Strength of service capabilities, reputation, brand.   If its being done in the world of IT, IBM is doing it and most likely on the leading edge.  The strength of IBM's offerings, the depth of expertise, and the true global reach in total are beyond those of any competitors.
cons: Respect for the individual is gone.  Senior management has developed a style based on an intense focus on numbers without regard to anything else. People are secondary.  Personal lives are for those in the unemployment line.  A reporting, micro-management culture has developed where executives with little knowledge of services and clients real issues make decisions based on numbers in a spreadsheets.  There is no loyalty towards employees - if numbers are missed it must be due to lack of effort or incompetence...employees are quickly and routinely cut as "new resources are easy to find".

review_title: IBM is worst place for salary and career growth
pros: Flexible timing and open work culture can make you happy for one or two years. You will be happiest person till the time your salary starts haunting your because of almost no hikes for years and years.
cons: No salary hike. No promotions. Every steps towards your growth in ibm is a big joke in terms of salary. To say the least, theoretically a person can become manager by the time his salary reaches 4.5 - 5 lacs (in case you are a campus hire or your have been hired at a low salary due to some reason). Every HR mail related to salary is a big Mathematical game to fool you. IBM gives no hike to average raters and they give 3-6% hike to top raters (only 10% of IBMer, that means on an everage IBM gives a hike of 6/10=0.6%. You can easily understand how pathetic it is...

review_title: Great Big Corporation to work for. Looks good on the Resume
pros:
1. Excellent work /  life balance options
2. Above market rate salaries
3. Tons of opportunities to learn
4. Large population of employees and big project teams lends exposure to diverse cultures.
cons:
1. Assignments can be long and hopelessly monotonous.
2. Performance rating system seems to be flawed. You may be held on bench earmarked for an engagement for future project by the Partners / RDM's; but you still will get less rating for your low utilization, which was not your fault in the first place.
3. Performance targets are set in Feb / March for the year. Evaluations for the year occur end of November / December, leaving first 2 months and last 1 month out of the scope. You are left to accomplish the 12 month goals in just 9 months..

review_title: IBM Poughkeepsie is an OK place to work
job_title: Advisory Software Engineer in Poughkeepsie, NY
pros: IBM is a giant company with many opportunities for leadership. In my experience, first line management is very understanding when dealing with life events both expected and unexpected. As a beginning engineer, you generally share your closed office with one other colleague as opposed to an open layout (i.e. cubicles).
cons: IBM Poughkeepsie is a very old site when compared to many competitors and even other IBM sites, and since there is no other large high tech company in the area, there are very few perks. Since the products we are working on have a very long history, there is a lot of legacy code and design that can be irritating to an engineer.

review_title: IBM has its ups and downs. it's secure if you're good , but costcutting has made it a dull and lifeless existence.
job_title: Software Development Engineer in Austin, TX
pros: Innovative people, flexible work schedules, chances to work on cool technology, and depending on your location, the ability to have a "one stop shop" of software, hardware, and services guys all in the same company and room
cons:
- The sheer size of the organization makes each VP operate like its own company, making them fiercely protective of budget and people. This squashes chances for growth at a personal level
- Smart and innovative people are leaving for other companies, and the remaining people are struggling to contain the work. Managers are even leaving now for other opportunities.
- Cost cutting has eliminated many perks, and even cut retirement plans (see IBM's recent change in 401k match contributions).
- Overall morale is low.

review_title: It's what you make of it
job_title: Consulting IT Specialist in Costa Mesa, CA

From a sales point of view, there are a lot of advantages like lots of resources (market intelligence, can get into any account, overlay sales/technical sales/product management willing to help).   From a technical point of view, access to R&D, development and some of the newest technology.    Health plan is excellent.... willing to even pay up to 75% for in-vitro fertilization.
cons: People may find it tough to navigate, understand the organization and company and network with other IBMers.    So many products and initiatives makes it difficult for the company and teams to focus on.      Team is very distributed and international.    Need to be self starter and be motivated to develop own career.

review_title: IBM is the worst company I have ever worked for.
job_title: Senior IT Specialist in Rochester, MN
pros: There used to be Pro's.  Management removed them one by one until there was nothing left.
cons: Management and executives are absolute idiots.  They treat employees like we are garbage.  No raises, no promotions, no education, no pension, no affordable healthcare after retirement.  Hopeless.  If you object management tells you that there are a thousand Indians who would love to take your job, so be thankful you still have it.  IBM is rapidly replacing all of their US employees with Indians, Brazilians, and even Africans.  They do everything they can to get the CHEAPEST labor possible and as soon as they do they kick their US employees out the door.  Executives try to fool investors into thinking they are making money by buying back stock at a horrendous rate while all the time IBM's revenues are drying up.  This is not a technology company, it is a farce.

review_title: Take advantage of training and get out.
job_title: Package Solution Consultant in Baton Rouge, LA
pros: Lots of training, looks great on a resume. Only useful as a stepping stone to a real career.
cons: Poorly organized, incompetent workers and disinterested management. Salary is less than half the industry average for the position I held. Endless stream of lies about roles, raises, and travel obligations. Places client demands over legal obligations to the state and employees. incredibly unprofessional coworkers with minimal education and zero work ethic. Zero communication between management and employees regarding client engagements, etc.  Misleading hiring process (most employees at our center were told they would be programming for mobile development, java, etc, but were instead trained on something entirely unrelated to their areas of interest).

pros:
-Brand name recognition is the biggest pro (makes switching job/applying to school a lot easier).
-Decent benefits and entry level compensation (including sign-in bonus)
-Unique and interesting projects available.
-Hours vary but are usually manageable for Public Sector (cap at 40-44 hours and partially remote)
-Travel perks (hotel points and mileage)
-Lots of people your age (if in 20s) in start class
cons:
-Lots of resistance and passive aggressiveness from upper management which can lead to a toxic environment.
-Lack of variety in projects (especially in public sector where options are severely limited) and difficult process in switching out (tons of paperwork and fighting amongst project managers at times).

review_title: If you are passionate and show your value you can go a long way...
job_title: Senior Project Manager in Somers, NY

Opportunities to have a lot of different jobs throughout your career, but remain in the same company.
Merit is a true statement here, If you deliver and prove your value, you will be promoted, can move to different challenges, can be sent abroad.

Great for leaders and leadership development

Work-life balance is really a challenge if you want to be above average.

Micromanagement, aggressiveness and lead-by-fear  (depending on our leadership) can cause burnout and make difficult work environments.

pros:

I don't see much of downsides, but few which I can say we have to improve in the organization. We are a huge process and data procedures followers, which can be optimised to the comfort of employees and management with equal accuracy and security.

HR regulations and interaction are very less, the tradition followed is to speak via emails. It is very difficult to get any news talents into the company though we … Show More

pros:
1. No issues with holidays or Work from home.
2. Having vacation is sometimes encouraged, if possible in your profile
3. Manager driven, hence no need to approach higher management every-time you need something done.
4. Appraisals and increments are based on internal assessments, hence fair enough.
5. Very ethical and great work environment, lots of opportunities to grow.
cons:
1. You should be lucky enough to get good manager
2. Internal movements are not easy, existing manager does not let you go in the fear that they will have to hire another.
3. They mould the passing criteria of Internal assessments as per their choice, sometimes it is 60%, other times it is 75-80%, depending on how much workforce they want to keep or they want to let go.
4. Managers do have the right to cancel the holidays given the workforce and circumstances, but this is mis-used by most of the managers nearly all of the time.
5. General bias towards Men, preference towards women, since most of the Managers fear women might complain against them and ruin their career, hence male workforce is easily motivated towards more share of work, by the managers.

review_title: Great opportunity in a sometimes tough environment
pros: Global reach, insights from lots of clients, access to new technology, excellent opportunities to learn.  Working in IBM you have a lot of freedom - you can build your own career and there are a great many resources you can call on.  The support for mentoring is very good, and the educational opportunities are pretty outstanding.  There's good opportunity to make more money by filing patents, and really oustanding support for developing new technologies even outside the day job.
cons: Job stability is an issue, morale is often low.  Management maintains a very sharp focus on cost take out, sometimes doing things that don't make long term sense in their eagerness to chase a good quarter or to achieve their targets.  Investment in services is very low compared to the revenue, and I don't always get the sense that IBM is really building for the future.  Your career won't happen to you at IBM, you've definitely got to push for it yourself.

pros: The working from home option is the only good thing about working at IBM Canada. IBM Canada does seem to employ a diverse work force.
cons:
Below market average for base salaries, very top heavy in management, too many layers of puppet managers whose hands are tired, any remaining benefits seem to be continuously being cut (health benefits, pensions, oncall pay has been halved or expected to be done for free!! etc). No training or education.
Heavy out-sourcing to cheaper countries already happenning in a big way - so no long term future at IBM Canada, unless you are in management to manage out-sourcing projects and have skills such as LEAN, SIX-SIGMA etc

review_title: All about talking and not doing...
pros: On the plus side, IBM does offer a good overall package to its employees and there are certain benefits to working for a global name; it can add something to your CV, provided you have the good sense not to stay there too long!
cons:
As has been stated above, a lot of work at IBM involves talking (and reporting) about what you're going to do as opposed to actually doing it. Regretfully this leads to people being judged more on their personality than their actual work.

I worked for Sun Microsystems prior to working for IBM (before Sun shut down our UK hardware R&D offices) - if ever there were two more contrasting companies to work for, I'd be hard pushed to find them. Sun relished individualism, nurtured creativity, and rewarded hard work, whereas IBM was more concerned with squeezing you into a box and talking the talk as opposed to walking the walk.

review_title: All work and no play makes IBM the place for you.
pros: IBM has some outstanding consultants and can do almost any project from business outsourcing through strategy/management consulting.  IBM is extremely broad and most people can find a place for themselves.
cons: IBM GBS is wrought with politics.  Even though IBM can do so many things ranging from software to hardware and finally services, getting the groups to work together is extremely difficult.  It is even hard within Services to get different Service Lines to work together.  Partners tend to worry too much about how their group is looking and not look out for the overall good of the company.  Additionally, when in global services, you never feel safe.  You feel that you could be layed off (resource actioned) out at any point in time.  Throughout this year, I have known a considerable number of top performers RA'ed due to billable numbers, and not need.

review_title: Great way to get frequent flyer miles
pros: IBM Global Services is a great way to get frequent flyer miles.  For the young and single and travel lovers, this is a fantastic organization.  I would recommend this organization to any recent college graduate with few commitments.  It was a great way to learn.
cons: The organization is so huge it is very easy to get lost in the shuffle.  The reporting hierarchy was strange, at best.  I had 4 different managers in my first 3 years with Global Services.  I never felt like any manager at IBM had my best interest in mind.  Someone once told me that the most talented IBM employees leave after 7 years or less.

pros: IBM looks good on resume
cons: Terrible pay, constant lies to employees, only stock holders matter, terrible raise if you even get one, favoritism for employees that kiss butt regardless of actual skill, CEO making 1000% more than average employees, corporate level bonuses from laying off good workers while the rest of us get pay-cuts and are expected to work even harder since those that were not RA'd yet. now the rest of the people are jumping ship finding higher paying jobs, respect and doing less work . now customers are affected since head count is so low and moral is all but gone. In short if you want to work for IBM think again, if you are still working for IBM get out ASAP. you cannot advance, you cannot make more money and you can be let go today, tomorrow no matter how good you are at your job. Your actual skill means nothing to management, the only thing that matters is numbers, made up fictional, political numbers, PBC is a complete joke. They are not a US company anymore and need to loose their tax break rights.

review_title: A challenging and difficult environment in which to work, but if being and thinking global is for you, choose IBM.
job_title: Senior Project Manager in Global Village
pros: You can choose to learn something about yourself and business every day and never be disappointed - there is so much knowledge in the organization that the challenge is filtering to what is truly important to you in the now.  IBM is your own personal MBA, such is the pressure and the challenge, but being part of a community that struggles and wins with you.
cons: Tough management, ruthless resourcing actions, bureaucracy, and your work is never finished.  This is a company where you have to be entirely self-motivating when the going gets tough, or when significant people are made redundant around you.  The performance ranking system can make for a dog-eat-dog environment where you have to outperform your peer to advance, and that can hurt collaboration or openness.

job_title: Technical Team Lead in Elgin, IL
pros: IBM offers a great deal of education in a shorter period of time than many companies. They are a process driven firm which helps individuals become familiar with their job role more quickly. They have moved to a pool environment in many areas which provides structure to each of the technical teams.
cons: The pool environment tends to limit exposure to other areas of technical interests. This also reduces the ability to focus on any given account or segment of the business causing customer dissatisfaction. The processes documented do not address much more than the most common courses of action which places some additional limitations on staff functionality.

pros: The best part of working at IBM is being able to engage with some very clever people.  As an older employee, I'm amazed at the quality of ideas and contribution of our University hires and early Professionals, and their willingness to share and teach.  You have to be prepared to work in a company which is transforming, and also understand that while your job isn't 24/7, the world is and decisions can move at a fast pace around you. Many opportunities to get involved in different projects locally, globally and virtually.
cons:
Matrixed management environment can mean decision making is complex and can involve many parties, so you have to learn the skills to manage people and expectations - often through email.
Get used to doing many things by email and phone which you might otherwise have only ever done face to face.
For travel, Economy Class on all flights (regardless of distance) is a negative.

pros:
1. IBM has got very selected talent above average. This gives proud feeling while working there.
2. IBM has got different streams for managerial and technical unlike other service based companies in India. This makes you grow technically and keep your interests aligned with your work. Unlike service based companies where after one level growth means management responsibilities and fetching business from customers. Your technical skills will become hell after some time.
3. Work life balance is very good which makes you more happy and deliver more. Happiness is proportional to productivity and vice versa.
4. You are encouraged to think differently due to the patent culture of IBM. This helps you develop a very different vision altogether.
5. Skip level meetings is also a plus.
cons:
1. HR services and account services are centralized
2. People managers still have some politics in themselves which can affect technical staff
3. Rigorous processes

pros: Wonderful colleagues, good health and dental.  Fairly professional in general.   Up until recently, working from home.
cons: Very toxic from an employment perspective.  For the last 15 years it has been a case of Russian roulette with annual resource actions.  The last 5 have been particularly bad as the fat has been removed and the staffing is far below minimum.  Off shoring has been a continuous churn with unqualified folks replacing knowledgeable resources and leaving IBM shortly after turnover.  Unrealistic project deliveries, due to under staffing and unrealistic scope.  Expectation to work above and beyond is a daily norm and the knowledge that if you don't you will likely be fired.  Resource actions now quarterly and move back to one of 6 centers are driving moral to new lows.  "new collar" and H1-b visas continue to drive employees away.

review_title: One of THE Top 5 brands to work for...............globally
job_title: Human Resources in New York, NY
pros: Continually re-invents itself to stay relevant to changing times.  IBM is 'World Issue' relevant, not just a technology services company - focusing on solving issues such as curing diseases, ensuring that expertise in areas such as healthcare, law, finance is available to ALL, no matter where you live or your socio-economic limitations, etc. IBM has had a focus on equal pay and diversity since long before it became a focus for other organizations. Career development opportunities are second to none, the internal movement of staff to new roles is a constant focus
cons: Sometimes it can be a little bureaucratic and overly 'matrixed' - but with 400,000+ staff its difficult not to have some of that..........pay/benefits are good but not industry leading - real motivation to join comes from the career opportunity presented, the chance for personal and professional growth once in IBM and the thrill of working for an industry leading brand which is taking Watson to the world.

pros: Huge Work Environment, Good for a start up grad, Good for a start up to know the False business tactics to ditch the customers.
cons:
No work Life balance, Poor wages, No Increment, very poor bonus even after working hard making the client happy, Too many internal reviews which don't make sense to employees. Managers force employees to complete the reviews quite often rather than concentrating on the real client satisfaction.
Unrealistic expectation to the clients - False promises to deliver produict to the client that work can be done. cannot take a vacation even if we are legally provided - too many approvals for vacation.
HR - Human Resource system is the worst I ever experienced ( Halifax, Nova Scotia)  HR never works for the employees. Just for a reference letter, HR makes Employees wait for 1 month after frequent visit and requests made (HR- Halifax-Nova Scotia, Canada) - Micromanagement from all around the management team - No support for requested technology but managers want the work to be completed on time. People at IBM doesn't work to make the client happy rather they work to make the managers happy. 
False vision - Equal opportunity employeer - IBM is /will never be an equal opportunity employeer.

review_title: As a designer, don't expect to move up
job_title: User Experience Designer in Austin, TX
pros: Bootcamp is a 3 month program (too long in my opinion) which is designed to give early career professionals a thorough onboarding experience/training. I feel like I can pull out a design thinking tool to solve any problem now.
cons: Bootcamp was way too long and they didn't give the option of doing industry if you had less than 3 years prior work experience. It will also make it extremely hard to move up as they lump you in with college hires and pay you the same. Good luck getting paid what you're worth here unless you are on a team that is doing extremely well.

pros: Started there as my first job and stayed for 12 years. Lot of opportunities to grow if you're smart enough to stop complaining and start working. There are good managers and bad managers as in all corporations. Didn't have a problem to change postion whenever I wanted. Participated and led variois projects always supported by managers. Generally if you like what you doing you could make it more or less exactly as you want it to be. I really regret leaving that place. For anyone starting technical career I can recommend.
cons: Money. Lets face it. It is a place made for the sole purpose of saving cost. It looks all shiny on the top with brand new laptops and quite modern offices, but the pay is way bellow market average and once you reach certain point you have a problem. There are positions with much more responsibility and impact, but no more money.

job_title: Product Design Lead in New York, NY
pros: Good stepping stone to a different job. Experience working directly with engineers and a variety of different job roles as a designer. Good practice advocating for users to people who aren't used to thinking about them.
cons: Where to begin. For one thing, IBM is letting middle management is drive it into the ground. Every step forward taken by very talented engineers and designers is eventually ruined by a complete lack of vision, strategy, and alignment by an unbelievably bloated middle management layer. Marketing teams are allowed to set product strategy based on questionable "market research" and also promises product capabilities to the public that are completely unrealistic (e.g. Watson for Oncology). It borders on unethical at times. There is no money for raises and promotions - unclearness and even dishonesty about this is rampant. There is zero transparency, and absolutely no engagement from HR to support individual employees. Every few months hundreds of employees are "RA'd" ("Resource Action," which = layoff).

review_title: Good teams but poor incentive pay
job_title: Client Technical Professional in Toronto, ON
pros: The best thing about IBM is it's people.  There are great opportunities to learn from others and you can usually find someone to help when you need it.  When there's a crisis, it's all hands on deck.
cons: Poor incentive programs for technical sales staff.  A portion of your base pay is held back (typically 15%) and you earn the rest in incentive.  However, without a true quota system, but rather a team quota which means a pool of available money is divided between the others on your team (basically profit sharing).  The pool of money varies depending on how your business unit performed.  Even when you do very well personally, you can still get a poor incentive bonus if the overall results are poor.  There is no insight into how the pool is determined nor how the money is divided amongst the team.

review_title: Diverse Project Opportunities / Training and Promotion Lacking
job_title: Advisory Project Manager in Southfield, MI
pros: Wide range of experience in different industries.  Opportunity to work with some very talented and diverse people.  My experience has been that there is some slow time at the end of projects that you can take advantage of after a grueling project (but not always).
cons: There are some incompetents at IBM, who are very hard to get rid of, and very frustrating to work with.  It's hit or miss when management addresses performance issues with these types of employees.  Formal training is lacking in my job category.  You are expected to find time to complete the computer-based training while you are more than 100% utilized on your project(s).  Promotion criteria is nebulous, and not communicated well.  There are so many "corporate procedures" to follow that you get lost with what's truly important while you are trying to do your day-to-day work.

review_title: If you are hired as a Supplemental - watch out.
pros: Excellent work-life balance, flexibility, and feedback on job performance.
cons: IBM heavily leverages "supplemental" employees, meaning if you are new in the field or have little experience, you may be hired as a "supplemental" employee. This just means that you are paid well below industry average and receive no benefits for doing the same work as regular employees, on the pretense that you are there to fill a "work shortage" for a short period of time.

review_title: Good place to be, don't stay too long
job_title: Business Development Manager in Dallas, TX
pros: IBM has lots of good technology and good opportunities across a lot of different divisions, ie Hardware, Software, Services.  The people are typically great, very smart and professional.  If you work hard and have results, you are typically rewarded.  There are lots of different opportunities for sales, technical, and management oriented people.
cons: IBM is a VERY large company with the accompanying bureurocracy.  The current environment in the US is a bit disconcerting - with everyone constantly looking over their shoulder for the next layoff.  Unfortunately, I'm not sure that will ever change as IBM seems to now use resource actions as they way they change business, rather than actually changing the business.  Therefore, there is no real loyalty to the company any longer.

review_title: Ok pay, good benefits and vacation
pros: 12 hour work shift means you only have to work 3 or 4 days a week. At least 2 weeks of paid vacation with the opportunity to earn more.
cons:
You have to work most major holidays including the 4th of July and Thanksgiving. They never have funds available for morale building events like they had in the past.

If you have issues with payroll you must call employee services where you are directed to a call center overseas. These employees have no real idea what's going, only a rouch black and white outline of what is suppose to happen. There is a HUGE disconnect between even the manager and payroll. 

When you leave IBM it is very common for them to over pay you and then either take the money back (straight from your bank account) or send you a bill, threatning to send it to collections if you do not pay.  They hire, fire and layoff thousands of people every year... you would think they would get this right by now.

review_title: Company to start your career in
pros:
Lots of trainings and development opportunities. Due to the high attrition and therefore rotation of people, there are growing opportunities. Good work is normally rewarded in the long term. 

Nice people, good ambient.
cons:
Due to the high attrition and therefore rotation of people, not always the best ones promote, so is likely to face managers and leaders with lack of people skills.

Overcontrolling company and tools. Lack of trust on people. Very low cost company. 
It is an IT company but IT works bad. Proprietary and free software is way worse than competition in most cases yet they force people to use it (Open Office)

People is not a priority. Work-life balance is damaged when you've some responsibility and want to do good.

Non competitive salaries and promotions. The best way to jump in salary is to leave the company and return, unless you ask for raises continuously.

pros: flexible work schedule. work with great people. great place for someone first getting in to IT.
cons: It can get stressful, especially when you are left to deal with the customer, when it is supposed to be the job of the account team. They hire anyone who has touched a computer. I have been with IBM for 2 years. never saw a promotion, can't apply for other jobs in IBM because I'm a critical player in my team, but people who have to come to me for help on a constant basis are favored for promotions. for a company that thrives off of innovation, whenever I innovated something, it took a long time, and a lot of reaching out to dead ends to bring my ideas and innovations to life. it is defiantly a company that looks better from the outside, than it does from the inside.

pros: Work for the oldest tech company in the world with the most patents filed every year -- we have a track record of world-changing innovation, and time and again we have transformed to lead the technology industry. Colleagues are bright and cooperative versus egoistic and competitive as you'd find at most consulting firms. Opportunity to help our firm transform as a leader in artificial intelligence. Flexible working hours and work from home, with better work-life balance than most consulting firms.
cons: So large that you need to look out for yourself in networking and getting interesting work -- easy to get lost unless you make the effort to know the right people and carve out a valuable niche for yourself.

review_title: Great for execs or starting your career, not for mid-level
pros: The diversity of people and experiences you'll find in your coworkers is great. The breadth of teams an opportunities means you can move around in your job without changing companies.
cons:
Senior leadership is completely disconnected from the people on the ground doing actual work. Also, every org cares only about their own revenue, which leads to massive inefficiencies as seven different teams in five different orgs with 6 different executives are all trying to do the same thing, and none of them are talking to each other or coordinating. 
From a development perspective, its all still run by engineering with no balance between them, product management and design. 
Also, 20 quarters of declining revenue and an abundant avoidance of risk means that everyone is anxious and pushing stress around without being able to actually do something to fix it.

pros:
It's easy to get job there.
If you have a friend who can recommend you to a high management sit, there is probably the best option for you. Management have no responsiblity for anything and have no real power to change anything. Every person is hiding behind procedures, which are bad for company itself and our customers.
cons: Everything. Job itself, job management, people management, thousands of useless tools and procedures ( which are chaning at least 2 a year, always for worst one ). Because of work conditions there is high team rotation.

review_title: IBM Rocket Center - Abandon All Hope...
job_title: Applications Development Specialist in Keyser, WV
pros: We recieve a paycheck, that is it.
cons:
I don’t know where to begin....

1) Rocket Center is the epitome of “Glass Ceiling”.  If you’re in the CIC, you’re a second class citizen. Period. They will try to tell you otherwise, but it’s painfully clear they don’t expect much from CIC and refuse to care about CIC employees.

 Many benefits (401k, time off, education  reimbursement , basically all benefits) are watered down. We get less matching that people who non-development jobs, and we are expect to work 44 hours without overtime pay.

Meanwhile the people who work “Staffing” jobs, the people with zero technical background, get paid overtime and receive a higher 401k matching. 

This is completely backwards.



The turnover rate at Rocket Center is insanely high. Seriously never seen anything like this. It’s a complete shitshow and I’m embarrassed to be a part of this.

pros:
-Work from home culture is great
-Pay is definitely strong
-Interesting products and services
cons:
-Company is on a serious downward spiral-
-It's a weird mix of really old people who've been here for 20+ years or new hires (within 5 years). The older people don't seem to want to mentor new hires and just want to make it to retirement.
-Ridiculous pressure to deliver short-term results at expense of long-term client relationships because the CEO's job is on the rocks
-Products and services are interesting but non-differentiating in a competitive market. Watson is solving a problem that doesn't exist.

pros: They have decent pay, some flexibility when it comes to working from home, and you will enjoy the company of most of your peers.
cons: Even though it is decent pay, living in Rochester is very expensive so it is still difficult to save up money. There are very few opportunities to climb the ladder towards management and even though they encourage you to be open about your professional goals, they will not let you pursue them unless it benefits your manager personally. There is an extreme lack of women and the pay and opportunities are not equal (though they claim it is). They expect you to work until the job is done but there is no overtime to compensate for the 60-70 hours a week you put in. Also, the turn around on employment is higher than anywhere else in the area (most people leave within their first 1-2 years).

job_title: Associate Project Manager in Piscataway, NJ
pros: Experience working with a global company is invaluable.  Many opportunities on the consulting side to work just about anywhere in the world there are IT needs.  Boasting wise - it is a world renown company which looks good in your portfolio.   If you take advantage of networking opportunities you can meet some really sharp individuals who can aid you in your career growth.
cons: The amount of time required to complete work often requires late nights, early mornings, weekends.  In other words, expect to work 50+ hours on a regular basis to complete just the bare necessities of your workload.  Also, formal training in a classroom environment is rarely permitted.  Salary increases is quite the exception for 'good', 'reliable' workers in or out of a recession.  Exceptional performers who produce intellectual capital and certify in various disciplines see an increase in their salary.

review_title: Be careful not to make too many commitments.
pros:
IBM has great health benefits for the employee and his family.  We have been very happy with our insurance.
Flexible Hours- IBM allows employees to set their own hours when it does not affect their work.  This can be an advantage when trying to spend time with family or a disadvantage when you have to work around others flexible schedules.
IBM allows employees in some jobs to work from home.  I have worked from home for a few years now and I like that I do not have a commute and that I get to see my family throughout the day during my breaks.
cons:
IBM has an overloaded workforce.  As a company they are downsizing their headcount while still attempting to do the same amount or more.  Workers are overworked and put in more hours than should be expected.
My position had limited advancement opportunities.  In technical fields it is hard to move up past a certain point without leaving the technical side and going into management.

pros: The atmosphere at IBM is relaxed and casual. This means that you can come to work dressed in jeans and a t-shirt and don't have to wear a suit and tie. Also there are no restrictions on what you view on the internet, unlike at other companies. So if you have time, you can check your mail or other things. You also have access to such things as Books 24/7, which means if you want to learn about some business or technical subject you can.
cons: Well, one of the biggest downsides is that people are treated as if they were robots. IBM, at least in Bratislava, is one big mess, where people are generally dissatisfied. The pay is low, especially compared to other companies. The benefits are also close to non-existent. It seems as if IBM was trying to save on everything. On the other hand they waste money on other things. The management is pretty incompetent a lot of times.

pros: Great variety in the company. There are really many opportunities to engage at IBM.
cons: A bureaucratic nightmare. Management at IBM is a lost art. You need to come to the job with all the skill and education required. Don't look to IBM to grow an employee. Executive decisions are opaque and seemingly random from an employee's perspective. (In fact, there is probably a lot of randomness at play). IBM has gone from three basic beliefs, with people being the top priority - to a company that doesn't really seem to know what to do with people anymore. The old IBM of Tom Watson knew that without strong people little could be accomplished. That does not appear to be the case now.

pros: If you are a motivated, career orientated individual and want to be in the same place for many years - IBM is perfect. It provides the clear ladder to the top and has an obvious and simple promotion structure.
cons: I entered as a graduate hire a couple of years ago. My training was poor to say the least. I was not given any training which was aimed at my particular role but instead I was trained with a group of fellow grads from across IBM (Sales, marketing, HR functions etc...) therefor the training had to be of a "lowest common denomenator" type standard where we learnt how to shake hands and answer a telephone. While I had almost 2 years of work experience and 2 degrees I was treated like a child for the first two years of work. Pay is also poor and the work life balance is fine unless you want to be promoted.

pros:
1. Good place to work if you are in good books of your managers.
2. Good place to file patents and you can safely skip your allocated work if you can file at least one each year.
3. Good salary and promotion if you keep on filing patents(even if they are kinda useless).
4. Best place to work as a manager.
cons:
From my personal opinion : I always feel that there is a strong discrimination on the basis of your mother tongue. Really feeling bad for this.. but nothing can be done.. 

Others :
1. Doing excellent work does not matter. 
2. If you are not filing patents or writing useless papers, you'll not be recognized, even if you took care of your allocated work.
3. Not good place to start your career in here unless you know few of the managers working in the same department.

job_title: Staff Software Engineer in San Jose, CA
pros: The majority of engineers are great to work with.
cons: Management changes frequently.  You have to prove yourself to a new hierarchy every year.  If you don't already have clout, don't count on your voice being heard.  Managers move up.  Engineers are underpaid and undervalued.  If you don't work as much as the workaholics, you will get a poor performance rating because of your "competition".  Anyone in my business unit who had a flat screen monitor had to buy it themselves because IBM senior management does not understand the productivity value per square inch of monitor screen.  Engineering is understaffed and overworked even when the business unit is making double digit profit for the company.  Senior management only cares about the percent productivity rather than the bottom profit line.
